subject: Thank you ♥️
body:
Hey {User},

In the last 137 days, I've sent 140 daily Finxter emails with tech news, LLM education, Python training, and prompt engineering. Thousands of informational emails since 2018.

Every day I get a lot of feedback and personal messages from the ~160k Finxters reading this newsletter ranging from "F**K Off!" to "Finxter changed my life!"

My gold standard is to answer every email eventually, even though it often takes a few days, so please be patient.

Today, I'd love to get your feedback so we can improve our value proposition for Finxters like you. If you choose to provide feedback, you can either

  • Scroll through the old collection of user feedback on the blog, and use the form at the bottom.
  • Rate us in the "How are we doing?" section below, or
  • Hit reply and tell me what you like, don't like, or would like to improve.

If you came for the content, feel free to check out this new opinion piece countering traditional investment advice.

Also, if you haven't already, feel free to check out the Finxter premium membership: we'll soon launch a new course on prompt engineering by our highly skilled star creator Dirk. ⭐

Finally, we don't spend money on ads - only on things that help you learn faster like content, OpenAI, or hosting - and rely 100% on word of mouth. I appreciate all support by Finxters recommending us to their coworkers, friends, and family members. This made all the difference for us.

I love you very much and I'm grateful for your support, your time, and your attention. ♥️

Happy Thanksgiving!

Let's be on the right side of change! 🚀
Chris

subject: AI Updates
body:
Hey {User},

Yesterday's Finxter AI Quiz has been quite well-received.

The average was 67 points. Only 10% of participants answered all questions correctly. And only 22% got at least 90 points.

My (non-technical) wife, who reads all Finxter emails got 90 points - so you don't need to be a master coder to become proficient in generative AI.

The most difficult questions seem to have been the following:

  • What is Huawei’s Pangu AI model known for? 👉 Learn More
  • What is unique about UC Berkeley's Starling-7B LLM? 👉 Learn More

I've added the links to the articles, so feel free to read up on those developments in case you struggled with those questions, too.

Before I'll leave you for your well-deserved Christmas dinner, here's an interesting resource from Meta I just discovered. You may use it to fuel upcoming AI conversations with your family:

🎵 Meta Audiobox Maker

Firstly, it has a solid text-to-speech (TTS) model that works quite well on your custom text.

But I found the interface noteworthy because it allows you to easily create Audio stories narrated by multiple speakers using a drag-and-drop builder and funny audio effects.

You can even download the MP3 and send it to your family or friends, completely free. Could be useful for a last-minute Christmas gift...

I wish you all the best - and thanks for staying with us! ♥️

Be on the right side of change! 🚀
Chris

subject: GPT-4 Turbo is here (FOMO never stops)
body:
Hey {User},

I don't know about you, but the constant fear of missing out due to the rapid acceleration of AI progress is killing me.

Once upon a time, Finxter was about Python education. But all I'm doing this year is catching up with the daily developments, trying to bring order into chaos to help you (and me) stay on the right side of change.

It feels like we're in the middle of a slow-motion intelligence explosion. The singularity is here.

Today, let's check out the new GPT-4 Turbo release, i.e., more powerful features, a 128k context window (enough to load a 300-paged book into a single prompt) at an API price that's only one-third GPT-4's!

[Blog] GPT-4 Turbo: 12 New Incredible Features at a 3x Reduced Price vs GPT-4

Think of all the insane apps you can build now! 👇

As a TLDR, here's the brand-new features of GPT-4 Turbo:

  • Pricing reduced by a factor of 2-3x
  • Context size increased from 8k tokens to 128k tokens
  • JSON mode for controlled output of OpenAI Functions (check out our course on Functions and embeddings)
  • Parallel and simultaneous OpenAI Function Calls (again, the course)
  • Reproducible outputs and seeds (e.g., to recreate the same image or character in an image for a consistent story)
  • Up-to-date world knowledge (cutoff April 2023)
  • One ChatGPT interface for all modalities (DALL-E 3, image processing, Plugins, Code Interpreter) without needing to select them in the dropdown
  • Acquire knowledge from external (WWW)
  • Image input for OpenAI API
  • New Text-to-speech generation capabilities (this is insane - the voices are like humans!)
  • New speech recognition Whisper 3
  • Introducing GPTs

The latter is a whole new rabbit hole to explore: You can now easily create your own flavors of little AI agents that are specialized for certain tasks.

How? With natural language "programming", i.e., you tell them what to do using words not code.

Then you can share those agents with the world - the idea is to have an app store of AI agents. And here's the kicker: you'll get a revenue share from OpenAI based on the popularity of your AI agent.

The latter is still a vision but one that's soon be implemented according to Sam Altman, founder of OpenAI.

Let me repeat this big idea so you don't miss it:

OpenAI creates an app store for specialized user-generated AI agents to perform any task imaginable that can be integrated into any third-party service like calendar, banking,  email, messaging, social networks, productivity, e-commerce platforms, ...!

As I said, FOMO is not going to stop soon. All we can do is take one idea at a time and run with it to see where it takes us. Rinse. Repeat.

Let's be on the right side of change! 🚀
Chris

subject: ChatGPT Made This Learning Path for AI Prompt Engineers
body:
Hey {User},

Several members of the Finxter Discord Mastermind Group proposed I put together a learning path for the courses on the Finxter Academy. I'm proud to say that they proposed ChatGPT would be able to do it. 🥹 

Great plan!

So, I used ChatGPT's "Link Reader" plugin to read all courses with descriptions from the URL https://academy.finxter.com/ and prompted it to create a learning path for the skillset "Becoming a Prompt Engineer and AI developer".

Here's ChatGPT's proposed learning path that focuses on developing skills in Python, OpenAI, and related technologies to master prompt engineering:

1. Foundations of Python

Course: Master the Single Line First! Top 10 Python One-Liner Tricks
Why: Grasp the elegance and efficiency of Python by mastering the art of writing concise one-liners.

2. Deep Dive into Python Data Structures

Course: Mastering Python Lists
Why: Lists are a fundamental data structure in Python, understanding them deeply will aid in handling data effectively in AI applications.

3. Advanced Python Techniques

Course: Python Magic Methods
Why: Understanding magic methods will allow you to create Pythonic objects which can mimic built-in types.

4. Mastering Prompt Engineering

Course: Mastering Prompt Engineering
Why: Gain foundational knowledge and learn how to leverage language models effectively.

4. Introduction to OpenAI's API and Prompt Engineering

Course: Prompt Engineering with Python and OpenAI
Why: Dive deeper into advanced prompting techniques utilizing Python's OpenAI API.

6. Practical Application of AI in Development

Course: Non-Hyped Exploration: A Practical Developer's Guide to Using ChatGPT for Arcade Game Development
Why: Understand practical applications of AI in game development and gain insights into real-world efficacy of AI tools.

7. Building AI-Powered Chatbots

Course: Creating a High-Performance Extensible ChatGPT Chatbot in 1 Lesson
Why: Learn to build a powerful and extensible chatbot using ChatGPT and other cutting-edge technologies.

8. Web Scraping for Data Acquisition

Course: Web Scraping with BeautifulSoup
Why: Acquire the skills to programmatically extract data from the web, which can be crucial for training and utilizing AI models.

9. Advanced AI Applications

Course: Prompt Engineering with Llama 2 - Four Practical Projects
Why: You'll delve into practical applications such as book PDF querying, payroll auditing, and hotel review analytics.

12. Continuous Learning and Application

Engage in various projects such as creating a joke search engine powered by ChatGPT, contribute to open-source, and continuously explore Finxter's new courses and materials to stay updated with the advancements in AI and prompt engineering.

Additional Notes:

Engage in the Finxter Discord Mastermind Group to share knowledge and seek support from ambitious, positive-minded coders like you. Ensure to build a portfolio showcasing your projects and learning journey.

This learning path will teach you the skills to be the core foundation of a profitable new career in the upcoming decade of rapid change.

Let's be on the right side of change! 🚀
Chris

 

PS: The Finxter Premium Membership gives you access to all academy courses, including the Finxter Mastermind Group on Discord.

We'll increase the price tomorrow (10/05/2023) by 20% to compensate for the increased costs and inflation.

Existing Finxter premium members and members who joined before the price increase (from $99 to $119) will keep the old prices for as long as they stay! ✅

subject: DALL·E 3 Trick: Using Seeds to Recreate the Same Image
body:
Hey {User},

I love scrolling through the OpenAI forum. In a recent post, I discovered this weird prompt hack of using seeds to recreate images in the new ChatGPT-V with image generation:

[Blog] DALL·E 3 Trick: Using Seeds to Recreate the Same Image

In a nutshell, you can paste a carefully designed prompt in the chat window that resembles an OpenAI API call. The trick is adding a 'seed' keyword argument (e.g., 'seed=4269') in the JSON-like image prompt.

You can find the specific prompt for copy and paste in the blog.

But here's the kicker: to the best of my knowledge, there's no official seed argument in the official API. It's an emergent phenomenon of this alien technology!

Sometimes I feel like, we're Stone Age men handed that enigmatic alien tech that are large language models. We hammer away at its intricate facade, and every so often, amidst our curious prodding, it sparks to life, unveiling glimpses of its wondrous, magical capabilities.

🔨🌌✨

Let's keep hammering - and, hopefully, be on the right side of change! 🚀
Chris

Here's the result of our recent community vote on the next courses on the Finxter Academy: 👇

As these are all super interesting, let's create not one but all four winning courses in the upcoming month or two. 🥳

Find detailed course descriptions at the end of this email.*

💪 Simple Action Step: Do you have any questions or lesson ideas on the courses? Now is your chance to hit reply and send me any questions or problems you may have concerning any of the four upcoming course topics. 

We've already started creating the courses "Coding with Purpose" (hopefully, Tom, who leads the open-source Peerbrain efforts) and "Prompt Engineering with Llama 2" (Yassin, our expert on prompt engineering).

So stay tuned!

Regarding the second most popular, "Intro to Python Programming", we already have multiple in-depth video courses covering this at the academy.

For your convenience, I've put together this learning path that'll make you a Python pro in a month or so:

  • ✅ Course 1: Python Crash Course

I still need to hire an author for the winning course.

If you feel like you're a great fit for creating "Fundamentals of AI and Machine Learning", this is your chance to hit reply and let me know.

Your course will be shared with over 150,000 coders, giving you insane visibility as a coder. Additionally, you will be compensated for your work via Upwork, following our established rate of $30 to $35 per video lesson.

👉 How to Apply? Please write 2-3 sentences explaining why you would be a great fit to contribute value to the Finxter community. The hiring decision will be made promptly within seven days, so please don't delay.

🎁 As a token of appreciation, allow me to give you our Finxter ebook bundle The Intelligent Coder with an original price of $89 for free via this link:

🔗 https://blog.finxter.com/thank-you-for-purchasing-bundle-the-intelligent-coder/

Enjoy the free books - and to your success! 🚀
Chris

 

 

*Here are the consolidated course ideas from the Finxter community:

  1. Fundamentals of AI and Machine Learning: Gain an understanding of AI and machine learning through a Python lens, with topics covering various machine learning models, model training and testing, and real-world applications.

subject: 🐇 Rabbit R1 Device - What's the Hype?
body:
Hey {User},

I just preordered the Rabbit R1.

Usually, I'm slow to buy the latest hot tech gadgets. For example, I never purchased VR glasses or expensive computing devices. I own a cheap Android smartphone and run my business on a commodity notebook for $499.

But some rare products are just too good to ignore. Tesla's M3 is an example. Another one is this:

🐇 [Blog] Rabbit R1 Device – What’s the Hype?

First of all, note that I'm NOT affiliated with Rabbit in any way. I don't get paid or compensated to write about their new device.

The second I read about the idea of integrating LLMs natively into an operating system to anticipate and deeply understand user intent, my mind was blown.

Finally, after one year of mass-adopted alien technology, we start to see more and more intelligence integrated into everyday products.

💡 'Nothing is more powerful than an idea whose time has come.' -- Victor Hugo

Rabbit's idea of tightly integrating operating systems and LLMs is fascinating. They may or may not succeed.

The idea, however, certainly will.

Check out the article for some pics and demo videos!

Be on the right side of change. 🚀
Chris

subject: New Llama 2 Prompting Course
body:
Hey {User},

I pay roughly $500 per month for OpenAI API usage. 🤯

~99% of that cost comes from FinxterGPT (GPT-4), which you can run on any of our blog posts.

Many Finxters struggle with this dilemma: Leveraging AI can become incredibly costly. But if we don't pay the price, we get left behind.

Wouldn't it be awesome if you could integrate high-performing LLMs into everything for free? 

Well, you can with Llama 2 if you do it right.

To help you do it, we just dropped a hands-on course, Prompt Engineering with Llama 2, on the Finxter Academy. It's free for all premium members! See here:

🔗 https://academy.finxter.com/

This new course is our fifth (!) prompt engineering course in a row. Unlike the other courses, it focuses on Meta's new open-source model, Llama 2, which you can access freely.

And if you have less than 700 million active daily users 😅, Meta's terms of service even allow you to use Llama 2 to make money!

Let's be on the right side of change! 🚀
Chris

subject: Mass Unemployment
body:
Hey {User},

 

We've had a few pleasant years with relatively low unemployment rates in the US, Europe, and Asia.

So, nobody is talking about the elephant in the room: mass unemployment.

🧑‍💻 [Blog] The Return of Mass Unemployment – Intelligent AI Bots, Expensive Capital, and Recession

And why should they? There's much more labor than people willing to work.

As long as there are problems, there is an opportunity to work. Because the nature of work is to solve problems, we will always have problems, so we'll always have work.

And in a healthy economy, people who solve problems will get paid.

However, I do think that we're in the middle of a paradigm shift.

As the Industrial Revolution unfolded in the late 18th and early 19th centuries, a massive shift occurred, with people moving from rural areas to cities to work in factories.

This shift was not seamless; many faced unemployment and had to acquire new skills to adapt to industrial jobs.

I worry that the transitional period may be tough for workers on the wrong side of change because they can only do work that provides little value if they don't learn and adapt to acquire new skills.

As a business owner, I'd rather hire one skilled prompt engineer than ten graphic designers.

The inversion principle suggests that to stay on the right side of change, you must keep learning and adapting. As you're on the Finxter newsletter, you're interested in tomorrow's tech skills and motivated to learn and improve.

Just keep it up - and check out the new article above for my detailed thoughts on this topic.

 

Be on the right side of change! 🚀
Chris

subject: Wait... is it sentient?
body:
Hey {User},

Today's email should be fun and playful: 👇

[Blog] Is AI Sentient? I Made a Coffee Break Python GPT, and This Happened 🤯

This will interest you even if you don't try the GPT yourself. Today, I figured we'd spend a few minutes on the insane reasoning capabilities within a single prompt reply and without external feedback of GPT-4 Turbo (see screenshot):

The image demonstrates GPT-4 Turbo’s ability to self-correct through reasoning within a single prompt response. 🤯 The initial response contains an error, but GPT-4 Turbo assesses the given Python code without external feedback and corrects itself.

This self-correction process illustrates a few key aspects of the model’s intelligence:

  • Analytical Reasoning: The model can analyze code and understand the logic behind it. When it identifies that the output does not match the expected result based on the code’s logic, it can deduce the correct answer.
  • Self-Evaluation: The model exhibits the ability to evaluate its own responses for accuracy, indicating a form of introspection where it can judge its initial response against the logical framework of the Python language.
  • Autonomous Correction: GPT-4 Turbo can autonomously correct its own mistakes within the context of the single prompt without needing external input, which is indicative of advanced problem-solving capabilities.

This self-reasoning ability is significant because it indicates a level of understanding beyond simple pattern matching or retrieval of memorized facts; it shows an ability to engage with the content dynamically and logically consistently.

This technology really is different and special. The emergent properties go far beyond what you'd expect a linguistic model to produce.

For instance, I watched OpenAI's lead developers presenting the new models - even they were surprised and couldn't precisely explain why they are as intelligent and sentient.

Alien technology, indeed.

Let's be on the right side of change! 🚀
Chris

subject: I tried OpenAI's API in async mode
body:
Hey {User},

In today's Finxter tutorial, you'll learn how to run OpenAI API asynchronously in Python:

🔗 [Blog] Can I Run OpenAI’s API in Parallel? Yes, with Python Async!

My main goal with this article is to refresh your understanding of "asynchronous programming", one of the hidden superpowers that scales the Internet.

Say you're building a chatbot system using OpenAI's API at the backend. How is a synchronous versus an asynchronous operation different?

In a synchronous chatbot, when User A asks a question, the system waits for OpenAI's LLM to respond before handling User B's query. If there's a delay for User A, User B waits, leading to inefficiencies during high traffic.

In an asynchronous setup, the system simultaneously processes User A's and User B's questions. Both queries are sent to OpenAI's LLM concurrently. Responses are relayed as received, allowing for faster, parallel processing. This ensures timely answers, regardless of query order or potential delays.

There are many subtleties to it but the simple gist is this: Users often want that a system feels synchronous but we coders implement it in an asynchronous way so that it scales to not one but many users.

You can copy and paste my code from the new Finxter blog tutorial to try asynchronous OpenAI API mode!

Let's be on the right side of change! 🚀
Chris

subject: Napkin Math on Human vs LLM Coders' Costs
body:
Hey {User}

Human vs Machine coder: Have you ever wondered how much a human coder costs per token output compared to a large language model (LLM)?

Let's do some napkin math. 🧮

Human Coder Costs Per Token:

The median wage for a software developer in the US is ~$53 per hour.

Assume an average typing speed of 50 words per minute. Let's multiply this with 125% to get the number of tokens output per minute.

So, with our average typing speed, we get about 62.5 tokens/min as coders, or 3,750 tokens/hr.

$53 per hour divided by 3,750 tokens per hour equates to a cost of about $0.01413 per token for a human coder. 💰

LLM Coder Costs Per Token:

Now, let's compare this with the cost of a large language model, which is estimated at $0.06 per 1000 tokens (GPT-4-32k)

Simple math shows us that this is  roughly $0.00006 per token.

That's how much difference?
👇

So, if we do a rough comparison, a human coder is about 235 times more expensive than the language model ($0.01413 / $0.00006 ≈ 235)!

235x (!)

That's a significant cost difference! 💸

Not all is lost though.

Programmers do more than write code - they design, debug, and communicate.

Most importantly, they engineer prompts.

When I realized this napkin math, it became apparent to me that we need to pivot as coders. In fact, if we manage to become prompters first and coders second, we'll remain on the right side of change.

That's the mission of Finxter - to help you remain on the right side of change. That's why we started to push into the LLM educational space a couple of months ago and we will continue to educate you on the latest LLM tools and prompting techniques.

To your success! 🚀
Chris

subject: Applying Metcalfe's Law to BTC
body:
Hey {User},

I spent four years obsessing about (computer science) graphs.

You know, the data structures with nodes and edges, not the plots. The first sentence of my thesis:

"Graphs are fundamental data structures in computer science. Wide-spread digitization generates massive amounts of interconnected, graph-structured data [...]"

Let's have a look at some real-world graphs:

  • In social media platforms such as Facebook, Twitter, WhatsApp, and Reddit, the 'nodes' represent individual users, while the 'edges' represent the connections between them, like friendships, follows, or likes.
  • In neural networks, like the one used in Tesla's Full Self-Driving (FSD) system, the 'nodes' represent neurons (or processing units), and the 'edges' represent the weights or synapses, which are the connections between these neurons.
  • For the Internet, the 'nodes' represent individual web pages, and the 'edges' represent the hyperlinks that connect these web pages to each other.

You can also model financial networks like Bitcoin, Ethereum, or the USD in graph data structures.

But why should you care?

Well, understanding graph properties is not only a crucial skill of computer scientists (as opposed to coders), it can make you a lot of money in investing and business too. 👇

An exciting characteristic of graph-structured systems are network effects. In particular Metcalfe's Law: the value of the overall network grows quadratically with the number of its participants.

Say you build a social network app with N nodes (=users). There are N*(N-1)/2 possible connections (edges) between those nodes.

The value of a network -- say, the telephone network, Twitter/X, or even Bitcoin -- is often proportional to the number of possible connections.

For example, consider this example social network

  • N=1,000 users => ~1 million connections
  • N=10,000 users => ~100 million connections
  • N=1,000,000 users => ~1,000 billion (!) connections

The larger your network becomes, the higher the value per network participant. (Read this again.)

We've seen this phenomenon play out in many real social networks.

For example, Meta's annual revenue per user was $5 in 2011 with 0.8 billion users, $20 in 2017 with 2 billion users, and $40 in 2022 with 2.9 billion users. As the user growth stalled, so did the revenue growth per user.

Savvy investors model the value of a network using Metcalfe's Law - that's the only way you could've justified an early investment in Facebook in 2011.

It is tough to disrupt the largest network because it tends to make the most money per user and can spend the most to acquire each user.

Don't try to compete against the dominating network in your field.

Even if you're Google and you're trying to build your own social network, you still cannot compete.

Now, the same holds for monetary networks like Bitcoin.

I did the exercise and looked at the dominating decentralized monetary network Bitcoin through the lens of Metcalfe's Law and network effects:

🔗 [Blog] Want Exploding Prices North of $500,000 per BTC? "Grow N" Says Metcalfe’s Law

To my knowledge, this is the first attempt to model the Bitcoin price using Metcalfe's Law by setting N to the number of Bitcoin nodes rather than the number of wallet addresses. The latter is not an optimal proxy for network size, given that exchanges may custody BTC for tens of millions of users in a single wallet.

The purpose of this article is not to provide a definitive answer on how the number of nodes can be utilized as a trading tool (although it appears to hold potential). Rather, the aim is to stimulate your thinking. If you find this approach useful, feel free to conduct your own modeling, research, or backtesting.

Feel free to share any insight you may have - I'll publish follow-up research on the Finxter blog and share it here in the community if your insights are valuable.

Let's be on the right side of change! 🚀
Chris

subject: This 1-Min Productivity Hack from 2019 Still Works in 2023
body:
Hey {User},

I'm a sucker for playing online chess.

Once I start a game on my work computer, my productivity takes a backseat for the day. There's something about the structured world of 32 pieces on 64 squares that my brain finds irresistibly calming. In fact, any game with a finite set of squares draws me in.

Years ago, I recognized that to achieve my goals, I had to minimize distractions on my work device.

I had to shut off the domain chess.com. Not only for my Firefox browser but machine-wide for all browsers, i.e., Chrome, Opera, Brave, and Edge.

And I did. And my productivity came back.

This realization led me to publish this blog article in 2019, which I just revisited and updated:

[Blog] How to Block A Specific URL on Windows (No Plugin, All Browsers)

It's still highly relevant if you want to boost your productivity! Reducing distractions is liberating.

On another note, I've incorporated community suggestions into an article I shared just a few days ago:

[Blog] How to Go From $0 to $100k Net Worth in 1 Year or Less (in Tech)

Enjoy today's easy reads. And please don't dismiss these ideas simply because they appear straightforward. There's beauty in simplicity!

Let's be on the right side of change! 🚀
Chris

PS: Wow, six years of online writing has undoubtedly influenced my choice of titles... 😅

subject: Llama 2 - No Saturation in Sight 🧑‍🚀
body:
Hey {User},

I just skimmed over the Llama-2 paper once again, and this caught my attention:

"Figure 5: Training Loss for Llama 2 models. [...] We observe after pretraining on 2T Tokens, the models still did not show any sign of saturation."

So, I couldn't resist to contribute today's Finxter article comparing Llama vs Llama 2:

🦙 [Blog] Llama vs Llama 2 - Still No Sign of Saturation!

You can find the impressive "Figure 5" at the bottom of the article.

It shows a simple yet profound relationship between how scaling up the number of model parameters leads to a significant performance boost ("training loss").

And there was no sign of saturation when scaling Llama-2 up from 34B to 70B parameters! 🤯

In other words, we've seen nothing yet. AI continues to improve exponentially. Intelligence is not capped at IQ 100, 200, or even 500.

No new research or scientific breakthroughs are needed to reach super-human performance in almost any area of our modern life. We only need to scale up computing cycles and data.

Yet - we can be certain that human and artificial ingenuity will add new breakthroughs that will lead to explosive performance and efficiency gains.

As you read this, LLM tech trickles down into every business and every job in every field.

The opportunity for most of us is painfully simple: Use your prompt engineering skills (e.g., obtained through the Finxter Llama 2 course) to create value for your employer, freelancing clients, or your own business.

subject: Tech investors arbitrage negativity bias
body:
Hey {User},

The future is bright.

Yet, negativity bias is a well-documented phenomenon in cognitive science:

  • First, things that are more negative in nature have a greater effect on our psychological state than neutral or positive things.
  • Second, stemming from this psychological state of overweighing negativity, media feeds us with more pessimistic views. We crave negativity and, therefore, gladly pay negative media with our clicks and attention.
  • Third, you will be labeled naive when you're crazy enough to share positive expectations. Some research suggests that negative people are perceived as more intelligent, competent, and expert than positive people.

As a result, third-party input data flowing into your brain is biased towards negativity.

From LLM training, we know what happens with input data biases - they become output biases ingrained in the neural nets.

But any bias is dangerous: "What gets us into trouble is not what we don't know. It's what we know for sure that just ain't so." - Mark Twain ✒️

Now, let's go to the more practical applications of this - how can we exploit negativity bias?

I think a simple exploit of negativity bias is arbitraging perception and reality of technological disruptions and exponential long-term trends.

We are famously bad in understanding exponential growth and compound interest. Exponential trends can easily lead to extreme positive outcomes that are 100x of what we initially expected.

  1. Ken Olsen (1977): "There is no reason for any individual to have a computer in their home."

  2. Sir Alan Sugar (2005): "Next Christmas the iPod will be dead, finished, gone, kaput."

  3. Steve Ballmer (2007): "There's no chance that the iPhone is going to get any significant market share."

This gross underestimation of exponential disruptions is a huge opportunity for tech enthusiasts like us.

We know that costs of AI training reduces by 70% per year, for example.

So, spending $100 on AI training will get us 10x more in two years.

100x in four years.

1000x in 2030.

The AI Scaling Laws teach us that neural nets keep improving in performance as we throw more compute, data, and parameters on the problem.

In other words, the intelligence explosion is unstoppable. Essentially, we have solved the problem of cheaply scaling human intelligence.

You can count on it.

So you better position yourself to benefit from change now before reality has caught up and change is here.

For example, we don't need to train a single human brain for 30 years, spending $230,000 to put it through medical school. We still can, of course.

But with LLMs, we can now also replicate this brain 8 billion times and put it on 8 billion smartphones giving every human access to first-class medical care, 24/7, basically for free.

When I talk about billions of humanoid bots, self-driving cars, autonomous AI agents, intelligent factories, replacing inefficient management layers from companies, automating policy and monetary systems, I need to do it with you as a fellow tech enthusiast and reader of this Finxter newsletter.

Because most people outside our little tech bubble don't understand the extent of upcoming disruptions.

All of it will happen much faster than 99% of people expect due to the exponential nature of declining cost curves.

Humanity has woken up dead matter and injected life energy and intelligence into it. We are in the midst of a giant and literal explosion (see PS below).

The future is bright in every meaning of the word.

Let's be on the bright side of change! 🚀
Chris

 

PS: Check out this conversation of Lex Fridman prompting Tesla's former head of AI, Andrej Karpathy:

Andrej: And so basically, it does seem like synthetic intelligences are kind of like the next stage of development. And I don't know where it leads to. Like At some point, I suspect the universe is some kind of a puzzle. And these synthetic AIs will uncover that puzzle and solve it.

Lex: And then what happens after, right? Because if you just fast forward Earth many billions of years, it's like it's quiet and then it's like tormal, you see like city lights and stuff like that. And then what happens at the end? Like is it like a poof? Or is it like a calming, is it explosion?

Is it like Earth like a giant, because you said emit roasters, will it start emitting like a giant number of satellites?

Andrej: Yes, it's some kind of a crazy explosion. And we're stepping through a explosion and we're like living day to day and it doesn't look like it. I saw a very cool animation of Earth and life on Earth and basically nothing happens for a long time and then the last like 2 seconds, like basically cities and everything and the lower orbit just gets cluttered and just the whole thing happens in the last 2 seconds and you're like, this is exploding, this is a state of explosion.

Lex: So if you play, yeah, yeah, if you play it at normal speed, it'll just look like an explosion.

Andrej: It's a firecracker, we're living in a firecracker.

Lex: Where it's going to start emitting all kinds of interesting things. And then, so explosion doesn't, it might actually look like a little explosion with lights and fire and energy emitted, all that kind of stuff, but when you look inside the details of the explosion, there's actual complexity happening where there's like, yeah, human life or some kind of life.

Andrej: We hope it's not a destructive firecracker. It's kind of like a constructive firecracker.

You can watch the video on the Finxter blog I just published here.

subject: The Mathematics of Scalable Wealth
body:
Hey {User},

I try to focus our Finxter Academy on exponential technologies. 

What are exponential technologies? I define them as technologies, products, and services in major long-term growth markets likely to grow double-digit percentage points (>>10%) annually for a decade or more.

The underlying growth engine of these markets is not marketing or business savvy but efficiencies of scale, network effects, and technological advancements and breakthroughs.

Adoption tends to happen gradually, then suddenly.

Primary examples of these booming long-term growth markets are alien technology (ChatGPT), AI training (NVidia, Tesla), Bitcoin, and freelance/remote work.

Simple insights like these will be the source of much of the newly-created wealth:

  • Will there be more or less AI in our everyday lives in 2030? More!
  • Will the demand/supply ratio be higher or lower in Bitcoin? Much higher!
  • Will there be more or less freelancing and remote work? More!

[Free Academy Lesson] The Mathematics of Wealth

Here's the elevator pitch in case you don't want to watch the video:

This strategic plan offers a roadmap to financial freedom for online coding entrepreneurs, emphasizing the need to scale active income (e.g., as a freelance developer) and gradually add scalable income, adhering to the timeless principles of wealth: increase units sold and profit per unit. The lesson further explains how to combine high-income skills, scalable business models, and boring investing principles to maximize net worth over time. The approach focuses on overcoming common barriers like limited control and scalability, guiding towards a lifestyle of comfort, autonomy, and personal fulfillment.

These are not my own principles but a shameless mix of principles and mental models from people more intelligent and successful than me. I am grateful to have discovered them relatively early because they helped me channel my tech skills into more profitable endeavors over time and break free from what I perceived as the "rat race". 🐀

subject: The Big Work Migration Has Begun (Billions Leave Their Jobs)
body:
Hey {User},

In 2016, I started my online business selling time for money on the free market as a freelance developer.

Back then, all of my colleagues planned to work in the automotive industry: seemingly a bright and cozy, 35h/week, $90k/y salary+benefits opportunity in Germany. 

But, I dreamed of what were then considered alien concepts: working from home, freedom from commuting, and spending more quality time with my loved ones. I wanted to break free, and become my own boss coming from a tightly managed employment environment as an academic researcher.

Few people agreed with my view that freelancing would eventually become mainstream, overtaking employment in population size because of its more flexible and adaptable work model.

Yet, I didn't expect the snowballing speed with which the freelancing industry would grow.

In the last seven years, we've seen a growth rate north of 15% per year. Statistics show that there are already 1.5 billion (!) freelancers. And the number of freelancers keeps growing relative to the 3.3 billion employed people.

So, long story short, if you want to stay on the right side of change, the data-driven decision would be to consider adding freelancing to your income stream. Even if freelancing represents only an additional means to make money that you can then reinvest to become an owner of scarce and desirable assets.

Freelancing is here to stay. What's the best way to start freelancing? Here's a quick guide on the Finxter blog that's still relevant:

[Blog] The Complete Guide to Freelance Developing

Also, freelancing combines beautifully with exponential growth industries like AI and Bitcoin. Here's an article that can help you stay ahead of the curve - most coders haven't yet tried Langchain nor Auto-GPT:

[Blog] Auto-GPT vs Langchain – What’s The Difference?

Let's be on the right side of change! 🚀
Chris

body:

First, allow me to express my respect and gratitude to Charlie Munger, who died today at age 99.

His 100th birthday would have been on New Year's Eve.

I watched all of Berkshire's shareholder meetings multiple times on YouTube; Buffett and Munger taught me a lot about business and the art of living with a long-term mindset. Most importantly, they taught me that everybody eventually gets the reputation they deserve:

"Another thing, of course, is life will have terrible blows, horrible blows, unfair blows. Doesn’t matter. And some people recover and others don’t. And there I think the attitude of Epictetus is the best. He thought that every mischance in life was an opportunity to behave well. Every mischance in life was an opportunity to learn something and your duty was not to be submerged in self-pity, but to utilize the terrible blow in a constructive fashion. That is a very good idea." — 2007 USC Law School

"You don’t have a lot of envy, you don’t have a lot of resentment, you don’t overspend your income, you stay cheerful in spite of your troubles, you deal with reliable people and you do what you’re supposed to do. All these simple rules work so well to make your life better." — 2019 CNBC interview

"I think that a life properly lived is just learn, learn, learn all the time." — 2017 Berkshire Hathaway Annual Meeting

"I have a friend who’s a fisherman. He says, ‘I have a simple rule for success in fishing. Fish where the fish are.’ You want to fish where the bargains are. That simple. If the fishing is really lousy where you are you should probably look for another place to fish."— 2020 Daily Journal Annual Meeting

subject: If OpenAI is Apple this is Android
body:
Hey {User},

Many have compared the new GPT Store with the Apple App Store. A powerful thought, but I haven't seen anybody think this one step further.

Let's recap - OpenAI opens up the creation of GPT-based agents on top of a closed-source foundational model that exponentially increases its capabilities using external data and third-party APIs.

Sounds like the Apple ecosystem with apps to me. Yes, OpenAI is in an excellent position to become tomorrow's biggest company in the world based on scaling intelligent labor. So far, so good.

But there's a gap that will eventually get filled: a strong contender committed to building an open app store on a more open-source infrastructure.

Think Google building Android.

Who will be the next Google building the Android of GPT stores?

I believe Meta has a unique opportunity in time to build its own GPT store based on its more open foundational model Llama 2. Read the article for more! 👇

[Blog] GPT Store Disruption – The Next Foundational Platform Will Dwarf Today’s Big Tech Monopolies

🧑‍💻 TLDR: The next wave of technological disruption will likely happen on top of one or two large GPT stores. Builders will have significant revenue opportunities on top of these foundation models. Investors who spot these trends early will get very rich. Think Google and Apple in the early days!

Build valuable applications using GPT 🔥, keep reading Finxter, buy scarce assets like Bitcoin, invest in AI tech winners. No financial advice. 😉

Let's be on the right side of change! 🚀
Chris

subject: More Prompts Than Atoms in the Universe
body:
Hey {User},

Nobody fully understands why LLMs work.

The best analogy comes from Simon Willison, aka. LLM = alien technology.

We don't know why a huge CSV file of numbers generates intelligent and useful responses, so we don't know the limit of the model's usefulness and intelligence.

Say you ask Midjourney to draw an image, but the result is garbage. You conclude that the LLM is garbage.

Yet, somebody else may be able to produce a fantastic image using the same model but with a slight variation of your prompt.

The model wasn't garbage after all - your prehistorian brain's ability to communicate with alien tech was!

One single word may completely change the output.

One word to go from garbage to world-class.

To prove this point, let's examine my daughter's most recent Midjourney article:

👉 [Blog] 50 Best Midjourney Style Prompts (New Version 6)

Here's how the character of the generated image changed by altering only one word in a 32-word prompt (Midjourney's new version 6):

REALISM:

PICASSO:

One word difference in a 30 word prompt!

Imagine what these models are already capable of - we haven't even scratched the surface yet!

Even if we restricted our prompts to 100 words of English, there are 

30000100

valid prompt variations given that many highly effective prompts are just bag of words.

It is estimated that there are only

1082

atoms in the universe!

Tell that to the many non-believers arguing prompt engineering is BS.

Be on the right side of change. 🚀
Chris

subject: We are still early
body:
Hey {User},

I bet you won't be surprised to hear the most frequently posed question from Finxters worldwide:

Is coding dead?
(Read: Can I still make money with coding?)

The answer is, of course, not at all.
(Read: Yes, you can make shitloads of money.

If coding were a human, it would be a toddler (1-3y) just entering early childhood (3-6y). Four-year-old children have different abilities and challenges than toddlers.

For instance, natural language becomes a more and more powerful tool in both early childhood and coding today - using tools like Amazon Q (see yesterday's article), GitHub Copilot, and just plain old ChatGPT.

🧑‍💻 Tutorial: Amazon Q and CodeWhisperer in PyCharm - A Visual Installation Guide with Examples

To stretch the metaphor a bit, an early child can get 10x more done than a toddler. Same for generative AI and AI-assisted coding.

You can talk to them, and they can reasonably interpret the deeper meaning of your words!

Some will proclaim that coding is dead because they don't use the powerful tools at their disposal.

Others will just use these tools to get 10x more done, make 10x more income, and create 10x more value for society.

🧑‍💻 Tutorial: 55 Best Ideas to Make Money with Python

The next paradigm shift, however, is just around the corner, so stay tuned. Finxter will be here to help you...

Be on the right side of change! 🚀
Chris

body:

  1. Bitcoin Whitepaper Cheat Sheet (PDF Download)
  2. I Used These 3 Easy Steps to Create a Bitcoin Wallet in Python (Public/Private)
  3. Bitcoin Whitepaper Poster (Printable PDF)
  4. Softwar: Why Jason Lowery Says Bitcoin Is a Strategic Military Asset
  5. 11 Best Bitcoin Books: Your Ultimate Guide for 2023

Regarding the best Bitcoin books, these two I found exceptional:

(1) The Bitcoin Standard
(2) Bitcoin: Hard Money You Can’t F*ck With

I believe spending a few hours learning about this "boomer technology" with explosive network effects and proliferating infrastructure helps us stay relevant.

In fact, I have written an article specifically on Bitcoin network effects and Metcalfe's Law.

Because no matter our biases as human NPCs, Auto-GPT and other LLM-based agents will definitely adopt permissionless "Money-over-IP" technology!

The Internet -- Text-over-IP, Voice-over-IP, Netflix-over-IP -- was built on top of the leading permissionless, decentralized TCP/IP protocol.

Similarly, the digital financial system of our cyber-biological meta organism will be built on top of the leading permissionless, decentralized value-over-IP protocol, named Bitcoin.

Don't let the protocol's playful and harmless name fool you into thinking it's just a fad. Protocols with large network effects can survive centuries. TCP/IP was invented in ~1974 and it still powers the Internet 50 years later!

Imagine how much opportunity a person would have had who understood TCP/IP in 1988.

Let's be on the right side of change! 🚀
Chris

subject: Meritocracy
body:
Hey {User},

Today, a long-term Finxter reader asked me for tips about hiring freelancers.

"How to find great freelancers?"

At Finxter, we're fortunate enough to have found a few exceptional freelancers. How? I only really thought about it deeply after getting asked this question.

It could be luck. But it could be something else because, as it turns out, we'll do a few things differently.

To share my perspective, I formalized my intuitive "let it go" strategy - and called it MBIT: 😄

🧚🏻‍♀️ Merit-Based Iterative Testing (MBIT) – A Modern Business Strategy to Building a Meritocracy with Freelancers

The idea is simple:

Rather than trying to control everything, micro-manage, and allow subconscious biases to reduce our decision quality, MBIT suggests letting freelancers self-select over time based on merit rather than academic degrees, impressive CVs, or other faulty proxies for job performance.

Check it out if you're interested in scaling your own online business. We all need freelancers to help us out occasionally because we cannot do everything ourselves.

Be on the right side of change! 🚀
Chris

Less is more.

subject: Can you solve this puzzle?
body:
Hey {User},

Can you solve the following Python puzzle?

fruits = ["Orange", "Strawberry", "Kiwi", "Pineapple", "Mango"]
vitamin_c = [43.2, 58.8, 92.7, 47.8, 36.4]

max_vitamin_c = 0
max_fruit = None
max_index = None

for index, (fruit, vitamin_c) in enumerate(zip(fruits, vitamin_c)):
    if vitamin_c > max_vitamin_c:
        max_vitamin_c = vitamin_c
        max_fruit = fruit
        max_index = index

# Fruit with highest vitamin C with index
print(max_index, max_fruit, max_vitamin_c)

You can solve the puzzle online to track your skills and check if you guessed the output correctly:

🐍 Solve this puzzle on the Finxter puzzle website for fun and learning

To improve your Python skills first, feel free to study our in-depth blog tutorials:

subject: 800 Years of Human Experimentation
body:
Hey {User},

A few days ago, Google Brain published a Nature paper that got some attention:

[Blog] Google Deep Learning – 800 Years of Human Experimentation in One Discovery

Google DeepMind’s AI system, GNoME, has discovered over 2.2 million new crystal materials, including 380,000 that are considered stable and potentially useful for future technologies.

In other words, AI researchers are already pushing the boundaries of human knowledge at a dazzling speed.

But is the progress in AI-enabled research sustainable?

Few have actually read the paper because there was an interesting nugget in the conclusion that I just couldn't let go:

"The test loss performance of GNoME models exhibit improvement as a power law with further data. These results are in line with neural scaling laws in deep learning and suggest that further discovery efforts could continue to improve generalization."

So it's not just me obsessed with AI Scaling Laws...

From an article on AI Scaling Laws that I am not getting tired of sharing with you:

The AI Scaling Laws could be the most significant finding in computer science since Moore’s Law.

As a programmer, business owner, researcher, or engineer - keep asking the one question: how to integrate LLMs into your value pipeline?

Because one prompt could put you 800 years ahead of your competition!

Be on the right side of change! 🚀
Chris

Because a single LLM intelligently deployed in a business process can free up millions of dollars worth of human labor in an instant. We just need to go out there and harvest those ripe and delicious fruits!

Again, the value creation opportunity for coders like you and me is insane. A business consultant or startup doing nothing else but applying and integrating the tech that's already there and easily accessible can save a business millions each year!

Why do I keep repeating these obvious things? Because nine out of ten persons still behave like the revolution is not happening right under there noses. It is unfortunate that it needs to be said, but it does:

AI is not another fad. LLMs are real. They are the dumbest now and get smarter by the day. Deploying them creates unseen amounts of genuine value. We are at the cusp of the fastest growth in human flourishment and economic power in history.

subject: This article on Transformers gets a lot of attention
body:
Hey {User},

I realized that a recent Finxter article is getting a lot of attention ("Attention Is All You Need" 😅), so I thought I'll share it as today's tutorial to help you stay ahead of the curve: 👇

[Blog] Transformer vs LSTM: A Helpful Illustrated Guide

TLDR? Both are artificial neural network architectures to capture the essence of the training data.

LSTM networks are recurrent neural networks (RNNs) specifically designed to address the vanishing gradient problem found in standard RNNs. They can learn and retain long-range dependencies and are often used for sequence-to-sequence (seq2seq) tasks, such as language translation or text generation. 

Transformers have gained popularity with the rise of generative AI (e.g., ChatGPT) due to their parallelization capabilities and the introduction of the attention mechanism, which allows them to effectively process large, complex sequences without getting bogged down in sequential data processing.

More in the blog! 🧠

Let's stay on the right side of change! 🚀
Chris

subject: Why I Hold TSLA
body:
Hey {User}

Let's zoom ahead 3-5 years into the future.

The recession is over, ChatGPT has launched version GPT-8 (manages your health better than your doctor), and Tesla has launched full self-driving (FSD) and is about to launch the Optimus humanoid bot.

AI training costs persist in declining 70% per year and the promised transformation into a new economy enabled by AI is in full force.

What does this mean for one of the world's AI leaders, Tesla?

I just completed a fun blog article on what I believe could be a possible per-share valuation of the Tesla company assuming the humanoid bot story plays out over a decade or so:

[Blog Valuation] Tesla Bot Valuation: $15,625 per Share Possible?

Here's the TLDR:

  • The Total Addressable Market (TAM) for functioning humanoid bots could reach $10 trillion per year, with billions of units deployed worldwide.
  • Tesla's strengths in battery technology, FSD, AI, large-scale production, and visionary leadership position it to capture a substantial share of the humanoid bot market.
  • If Tesla captures 25% of the market, this equates to roughly $2.5 trillion in annual profit due to the high software profit margins north of 50%. 
  • At a Price/Earnings (P/E) ratio of 20, conservative compared to some high-growth tech companies, this would give a market capitalization of $50 trillion.
  • With approximately 3.2 billion shares outstanding, this would equate to a share price of $15,625. Currently, it's at $280 so this would represent a 55x.

Crazy numbers, right?

Yes, this valuation represents just one potential path based on the success of Tesla's humanoid bot program and the broader acceptance of humanoid bots in society.

And you'd have to perform a probability-weighted expected value calculation. However, I believe the fact that this scenario is not too unlikely should make us stop and think.

To position ourselves on the right side of change, sometimes we need to become owners rather than stay busy workers forever. I don't say you should buy Tesla stock like me.

I'm not an investment advisor and you shouldn't consider this investment advice obviously. I'm just a random guy from the Internet after all.

But I'm convinced that many of the benefits of automation will accrue to the owners of the few companies that'll win the AI race.

Ownership is important. Yet, statistically, only 20 to 25% of Finxters own stocks. Three out of four Finxters won't benefit from the appreciation of the stock market due to wild efficiency gains.

I want all Finxters to succeed - so if you're one of 75%, this may serve as a slight nudge to consider.

To your success! 🚀
Chris

subject: The Art of Clean Code (7/10) - The Unix Philosophy
body:
Hey {User},

The Unix ecosystem is one of the most beautiful collective achievements in the history of human collaboration.

In today's email, I've compiled the 15 most insightful Unix principles we can use to become better coders, AI developers, or prompt engineers:

👉 The Art of Clean Code – 15 Unix Principles

  1. Make each program do one thing well
  2. Simple is better than complex
  3. Small is beautiful
  4. Build a prototype as soon as possible
  5. Choose portability over efficiency
  6. Store data in flat text files
  7. Use software leverage to your advantage
  8. Avoid captive user interfaces
  9. Make every program a filter
  10. Worse is better
  11. Clean code is better than clever code
  12. Design programs to be connected with other programs
  13. Make your code robust
  14. Repair what you can—but fail early and noisily
  15. Write programs to write programs

They are as relevant today as ever!

Be on the right side of change. 🚀
Chris

subject: Ten Career Paths Post-GPT
body:
Hey {User}

Today I thought it'll be fun to dive into ten career paths that are likely to work post AI, these are aggregated by Finxter Emily.

TLDR - Here's a short-form version of the article:

  • AI Ethics Officer: Ensures AI doesn't discriminate or harm, like preventing an AI system from rejecting job applications based on gender; $80,000 – $200,000. I bet this one will be massive based on today's "woke" society.
  • AI Trainer: Like a coach for AI, corrects its mistakes and teaches it to understand human speech or recognize images; $75,000 – $150,000. Autolabeling may be a threat though.
  • Mental Health Professional: Helps people through tough times, like a therapist listening to someone dealing with grief; $45,000 – $130,000. Mental health will be disrupted by AI eventually but most of it will be additional demand by "normal people" needing professional coaching and seeking personal development, IMO.
  • Environmental Engineer: Designs ways to install solar energy (booming!), clean oceans, or reduce pollution, such as creating sustainable waste management systems; $60,000 – $120,000.
  • Special Education Teacher: Tailors lessons for children with disabilities, such as using visual aids for a child with hearing impairment; $40,000 – $80,000.
  • Healthcare Provider: Takes care of patients, like a nurse assisting in surgery or a doctor using AI for early cancer detection; $80,000 – $300,000+.
  • Social Worker: Acts like a guiding friend, helping a struggling family find housing or a job; $40,000 – $80,000.
  • Research Scientist: Explores new frontiers, like discovering a new material that makes solar panels more efficient; $70,000 – $160,000.
  • Creative Artist: Paints, sculpts, or writes to express emotions or ideas, like an artist painting a mural that brings a community together; $20,000 – $100,000+.
  • Human Resources Manager: Like a matchmaker for companies and employees, finds the right people for the right jobs and helps them settle in; $65,000 – $200,000.

Personally, I'd add coding work that builds on and leverages LLM APIs and LLM-based meta tools such as auto GPTs and simply prompt engineering, as well as Bitcoin development on L2 (e.g., Lightning). Both are six-figure opportunities for sure.

You can read the full blog guide with beautiful visuals here:

👉 [Blog] Ten Sustainable Career Paths in the Post-AI Economy

Greetings from Hamburg, Germany. 🚢

 

Let's stay on the right side of change! 🚀
Chris

subject: Worldcoin – Follow the Money
body:
Hey {User}

"I’m really disappointed to see you so gleefully promote putting people out of work. It’s not what I’m interested in using AI for."

Lately, I've been receiving feedback by some Finxter readers similar to this.

I deserve it, too, because I continue to be highly excited about the upcoming disruptions brought about by two significant forces: AI and Bitcoin.

(1) Artificial intelligence

LLMs like ChatGPT will put legions of knowledge workers out of work. The world is awakening as we continue to put pretrained brains serialized into highly compressed files in the form of LLMs into every imaginable object.

Intelligence is no longer a scarcity.

This is a transformational change as all things become aware and intelligent - all products must be rethought. Opportunities to create value and ripe low-hanging fruits by integrating LLMs into X are endless.

We are already on an exponential curve in AI training cost efficiency, the number of robots deployed, and other metrics measuring rapid change.

Never underestimate the disruptive power of exponential change.

(2) Bitcoin

Bitcoin stands to mitigate the limitations introduced by large banking institutions and corporate finance. It represents freedom money, retaining its value while being transferred across distances and time.

Considering traditional finance systems like VISA levy a fee on every transaction, traditional financial systems can be likened to sucking out our life energy, if I may borrow Saylor's metaphor.

I think if you focus on these two technology disruptions, i.e., AI and Bitcoin, you're well-equipped to stay on the right side of change.

Now, focusing is easier said than done, especially in our world of distractions.

For instance, many Finxters these days send me questions on the following new centralized technology startup.

👁️ [Blog] Worldcoin – Who Pays for Universal Basic Income (UBI)?

The premise of the project, cofounded by ChatGPT founder Sam Altman, is that humanity will eventually need universal basic income to fairly distribute the efficiency gains of "putting people out of work" (see the first sentence of this email).

While I believe the idea of UBI is sound, I'm not a fan of the token or centralized crypto projects like this one (no matter how often they use the term "decentralization" to distract our focus.

But read for yourself - where does the money come from?

The future is bright - let's stay on the right side of change! 🌞
Chris

 

PS: Welcome to our new Finxter Premium Members! Please give me a few days to reply - I have been swamped with emails, but I'll eventually reply.

You can view my slow response time as "proof of humanity". 😅

subject: The Scarcest Resource on Earth
body:
Hey {User}

What is the scarcest desirable resource on Earth?

Before you read on, I want you to commit to an answer.

Is human time the scarcest resource?

No. You can always produce more humans. Your human time might be limited but human time in general is a renewable resource.

Is energy the scarcest resource?

Well, no. Energy is infinite, and it is all around us. The sun is a giant fusion reactor in the sky, and only a tiny portion of its emitted energy arrives on Earth.

Think of the sun's energy as Niagara Falls, but trillions of times larger, pouring out light instead of water. The tiny fraction that reaches Earth is over 10,000 times our total energy use.

If harnessed effectively, it could power our world many times over.

Is USD the scarcest resource?

You are on the right track, but no. They wouldn't print it in the trillions if fiat money were scarce. Look at any chart of the money supply growth (M1, M2, M3) - they are all up to the right exponentially. 📈

Not how the supply of a scarce resource looks like.

What about gold or diamonds?

Gold is one of the scarcest resources on Earth. Yet it has an annual supply growth of 2% per year. We mine more and more gold without an upper limit.

If the price of gold were to go ballistic (e.g., 10x), gold miners would profitably mine much more gold. With increasing gold supply, the prices would start to go down again.

The world economy is a self-regulating organism.

As for diamonds, despite their reputation for rarity, they are actually more common than gold when you look deep within Earth. You can even synthetically produce diamonds, so if the price rises, you'd mass-produce them, and the price would drop again.

Neither gold nor diamonds are the scarcest resources on Earth.

What about scarce and desirable real estate?

Think of rare, prime real estate as the 'Picassos' of the property world. Like original works of art from a master painter, there's a finite amount of this prime property, especially in desirable areas like beachfronts or city centers.

To illustrate, imagine the Manhattan skyline as a limited-edition collection of sculptures. Once they're all taken, there's no more space for new ones - the only way to get one is if someone decides to sell theirs. This is why Manhattan real estate is among the most expensive globally; there's high demand, but the supply is fundamentally limited.

In this sense, rare real estate can be as scarce as a precious gem.

Yet - there's always more land. Earth is big. There are 695,000 miles of coastline, 29 times the Earth's circumference.

We could build more real estate in the desert, under the sea or floating on it, on Mars, or just into the sky.

If you think about it, we'll even build more real estate in digital worlds as more and more of our lives move into cyberspace. That's one of the reasons Apple and Meta, two of the most profitable companies, focus on building virtual reality devices.

Is it intelligence?

Not with the recent intelligence explosion we've been witnessing. During the last few months, I've written extensively about LLM technology, AI, and ChatGPT.

Our collective intelligence will go 1,000x over the next couple of decades.

So what is the most scarce resource on Earth?

The answer is ... Bitcoin!

Plain and simple.

Bitcoin is a monetary good with a fixed supply schedule. There will always only be 21,000,000 BTC units. Each is infinitely divisible but there cannot be more BTC without changing the protocol.

Unlike gold, diamonds, real estate, human time, intelligence, and any other good on Earth, you cannot produce more of it when the price increases.

When more miners try to generate more BTC, the difficulty adjustment will make it harder to produce it. This protects the cap of 21 million monetary units from being hacked by higher energy expenditure and increasing human ingenuity.

It is desirable. You can use it as the official payment instrument in a handful of countries already (like El Salvador).

There are an estimated 56 million millionaires in the world as of 2023. This number is expected to grow to 87.5 million by 2026. Fiat inflation will continue to produce more and more millionaires forever.

So not every USD millionaire can have a single Bitcoin, even though every USD millionaire will want one to diversify and protect their net worth.

The only reason this scarce monetary protocol works is decentralization (otherwise, it would become a fiat currency controlled by a single party). That's also why the 20k+ other cryptos are inferior: they are less decentralized.

Soon an infinite number of intelligent agents based on LLMs and other AI technologies will start to acquire the scarcest good on Earth, which makes it even more scarce for ordinary people like you and me.

US presidential candidates now propose to buy BTC to stabilize the US balance sheets.

The biggest asset managers in the world -- Blackrock, Fidelity, BNY Mellon, Vanguard -- have already started to accumulate BTC and will keep doing so.

The US will soon see a Bitcoin ETF, and a tsunami of new retail capital will compete for the scarcest resource on Earth.

Nothing is inevitable, but objectively, Bitcoin is and is likely to remain the scarcest resource on Earth.

To your success! 🚀
Chris

subject: Here's to the misfits.
body:
Hey {User},

"Here's to the crazy ones. The misfits. The rebels. The troublemakers. The round pegs in the square holes. The ones who see things differently." - Steve Jobs

I hate Instagram - it's all posing, testosterone, and the embodiment of the shiny object syndrome. It's wasted time and life energy, so I've learned to avoid it like the plague.

But here's something I love: Midjourney.

Even though it's often misused to create fake Instagram models of perfect people and places.

They are all so perfect! 🦋🙄

But what about the misfits? What about boring everyday persons and situations - workers shuffling dirt, people in the subway, everyday dishes that don't get millions of views on Instagram with their perfect presentation?

Can we create those images with Midjourney, even though it (superficially) seems to be trained with a bias toward perfect, beautiful people?

The answer is a resounding yes!

👇👇👇

You can -- if you use what you may call the Boring Prompt:

🥱 [Images] The Boring Midjourney Prompt: Create Random Boring Photos of Everyday Situations

I discovered it when researching ways to create images of normal everyday people and situations.

Here are two examples:

❌ What We Don't Want:

✅ What We Want:

Check out the article if you're interested in the prompt - it can be super useful for many situations and apps.

For example, this prompt could be the bread and butter of your disruptive visual Character AI clone combining AI characters with social networks?! 😉

Many Finxters struggle with their career choices. A typical question I have personally replied to thousands (!) of times:

To this end, I just created a fun prompt (GPT) that can help you get some clarity:

The prompt is designed to guide you through these three steps.

subject: Python Entrepreneur Habits
body:
Hey {User},

I just designed this Python puzzle that also may give you some ideas on powerful daily habits you can start implementing today to compound your success. (Or you can just solve it for fun. 🧑‍💻)

🔗 *** Solve Python Puzzle Online (Interactive) ***

🐍🐍🐍

class Entrepreneur:
    def __init__(self):
        self.habits = {
            "learning": False,    # Have you engaged in daily learning?
            "tasks": False,       # Are your top 3 tasks for the day completed?
            "network": False,     # Did you connect with someone in your network today?
            "mindful": True,      # Are you practicing mindfulness or meditation?
            "exercise": True,     # Did you engage in physical activity?
            "finance": False,     # Was there a review of business finances today?
            "feedback": True,     # Did you seek feedback on something?
            "focus": False,       # Were there periods of focused, undistracted work?
            "skills": True,       # Was time spent on skill development?
            "gratitude": True     # Did you reflect on things they're grateful for?
        }

    def __getitem__(self, habit):
        return self.habits.get(habit, False)

    def __setitem__(self, habit, value):
        if habit in self.habits:
            self.habits[habit] = value

    def day_summary(self):
        return sum(self.habits.values())

    def toggle_habit(self, habit):
        self[habit] = not self[habit]

person = Entrepreneur()
person.toggle_habit("learning")
person.toggle_habit("mindful")
person["tasks"] = True

print(person["learning"], person.day_summary())

🐍🐍🐍

What's the output of this puzzle?

Take your time to solve it and strengthen your Python skill. You can also have an interactive and more readable puzzle version on the Finxter app and track your Python skills here:

🔗 *** Solve Python Puzzle Online (Interactive) ***

Have fun - enjoy the start of the week.

Let's be on the right side of change - with the right habits! 🚀
Chris

subject: From AI Scaling to Mechanistic Interpretability
body:
Hey {User},

After the popularity of our recent article on AI scaling laws, let's go one step deeper into the rabbit hole and learn about a brand-new concept that only advanced machine learning engineers know: mechanistic interpretability.

💡 Mechanistic interpretability is an important AI concept that takes neural net weights and basically reverse-engineers what algorithms they’ve learned to perform well on a task.

👇👇👇

[Blog] From AI Scaling to Mechanistic Interpretability

👆👆👆

For example, if you reverse engineer code, you may try to guess Python code from binary (executable) code. In mechanistic interpretability, we go from parameters to knowledge (e.g., algorithms).

This new computer science concept is definitely worth spending today's email on - because you'll probably hear it often in the future.

Let's stay on the right side of change! 🚀
Chris

subject: Alien Technology
body:
Hey {User}

Nobody fully understands how and why the magical technology LLM works.

The best mental model I've seen comes from Simon Willison, who calls LLMs "Alien Technology" that was handed to us a couple of months ago, and we're just starting to explore it. 👇

[Blog] Alien Technology: Catching Up on LLMs, Prompting, ChatGPT Plugins & Embeddings

What we know is the following:

OpenAI, under the guidance of Sam Altman, recognized the immense potential in the transformer architecture proposed in the 2017 paper "Attention Is All You Need".

Interestingly, this was a Google and Google Brain Research paper, but Google's own researchers didn't understand the implications of their discovery themselves.

In a Lex Friedman podcast, Sam Altman mentioned that the breakthrough happened when they decided to boldly push the scale of computing and data farther than anyone else.

We’re talking about millions of dollars spent on cutting-edge computing power and terabytes of textual data to train these models. From what we know, the training data seems to include massive amounts of pirated books and copyrighted content such as the Harry Potter series - only that the LLM obfuscates the copyright issues.

It’s a gargantuan effort that converges in a matrix of numbers — the model’s parameters — that represent the learned patterns of human language.

By using an unprecedented amount of computing on an unprecedented amount of data on a simple neural network architecture (transformers), intelligence seems to be an emergent phenomenon.

I’d go as far as to say that the age-old process of reproducing human intelligence has been transcended. Intelligence is solved. LLMs will only become smarter from now on. Like the Internet, LLMs will stay and proliferate and penetrate every single sector of our economy.

LLMs are densely compressed human wisdom, knowledge, and intelligence. Now imagine having these files and being able to copy them millions of times, running them all at once.

So picture this: Millions of intelligent student workers that are eager to work day and night on anything you want. How would you use them?

In this email, I want to challenge you to think of novel use cases for millions of intelligent workers working virtually for free. Because the only limitation I see now and in the upcoming decades seems to be your imagination.

Let's stay on the right side of change! 🚀
Chris

 

PS: I may be slow to respond to emails for the next few weeks as I'll be on a road trip to Denmark with limited Wifi access. Don't worry if I skip a daily email or two. I'll be back to my speedy self once I'm back online. Thanks for understanding!

subject: Riding the Change Tsunami
body:
Hey {User},

This year has made it clear that disruption is just around the corner.

Every Finxter email ends with "Be on the right side of change". Let's talk about that - how to be on the right side?

Nobody knows for sure, but we can identify some behavioral patterns. For simplicity, I categorized three personas and how they position themselves in today's world:

(1) Overt Deniers 🥸 *minority*: "Why would anyone ever need an automobile when we have perfectly good horses?"
(2) Passive Observers 👀 *majority*: "I read the Bitcoin whitepaper in 2015 and found it very interesting. But I found paying $300 per BTC too expensive, so I didn't buy any."
(3) Strategic Navigators ⛵ *minority*: "I watched an interview with Elon Musk in 2013, believed in his ability to make things happen, and bought a modest 1000 shares equivalent for $3/share. Today, this TSLA position alone is worth $218,000.

Only group (3) anticipates change, acts accordingly, and benefits massively from explosive, exponential disruptions.

Check out today's Finxter article on the topic:

[Blog] Forecasting Isn’t Enough: The Art of Riding the Change Tsunami

Thanks for being an avid Finxter reader. It keeps humbling me to see 150k Finxters reading this daily email newsletter. ♥️

Let's be on the right side of change! 🚀
Chris

subject: The Art of Clean Code (9/10) - Focus
body:
Hey {User},

Let's recap the eight core lessons and the unifying principle in The Art of Clean Code:

👉 The Art of Clean Code – Focus as the Ultimate Weapon to Fight Entropy

If you take only one thing out of this 10-part tutorial series, it's that focus is everything.

  • Unix lingo: Do One Thing Well
  • Bill Gates: Focus Is The Most Important Thing in Business
  • Elon Musk: Delete. Delete. Delete.

TLDR: Complexity leads to deadly Entropy. Productivity is reducing Entropy. We reduce Entropy by using focused effort:

  • Focus on the most productive 20% (80/20 Principle).
  • Build and iterate on minimal viable products (MVP).
  • Write concise code (17 Principles).
  • Avoid premature optimization (Six Types).
  • Foster a focused environment (Flow).
  • Simplify code with Unix's approach of doing one thing well.
  • Design with minimalism for clarity and effectiveness.

Check out the blog above for a quick rush through the most important concepts addressed in the last eight lessons of the book!

Be on the right side of change. 🚀
Chris

subject: LLM = Copyrighted Data Laundering?
body:
Hey {User},

Imagine your hacker friend Alice sends you three pirated coding ebooks.

For example, let's make it Python One-Liners, The Art of Clean Code, and The Book of Dash. 😉🏴‍☠️

You're a law-abiding citizen so you decide to remove Alice's pirated ebooks from your computer. But then a thought crosses your mind - before removing the books from your device, you could read them first.

The books have been stored on your device anyway, so why not read them first and only then remove them? The outcome is the same.

So you read the books, learn something new, and remove them from your device.

Your biological neural net has become more competent because it now understands Python's ins and outs, the practicalities of creating successful code projects, and how to create beautiful dashboard applications.

After deleting the copyrighted material from your computer, the only trace of the pirated books is in the form of newly created synapses in your brain.

Your future output (e.g., speech or writing) may be partially based on the copyrighted material.

But what actually comes out of your mouth is not a copyright violation only because you've consumed copyrighted material. Your output is a mix of everything you've ever consumed and, possibly, some of your own thoughts on top.

That's roughly how ChatGPT and other LLMs did it: they learned from thousands of copyrighted ebooks like Harry Potter without actually violating copyright law. 👇

[Blog] Top 10 LLM Training Datasets – It’s Money Laundering for Copyrighted Data!

Although I'm one of the authors whose material has been used without compensation, it doesn't bother me. Between you and me, I'm super happy and grateful that AI companies worldwide have had the guts to freely use the body of human knowledge to train their giga brains and launch the LLM revolution.

Knowledge wants to be free.

Also, after yesterday's lesson 1, make sure to check out lesson 2 of our free course on OpenAI API Mastery - Function Calls and Embeddings: 👇

[Blog] OpenAI API Functions & Embeddings Course (2/7): Function Calls with Parameters

Tomorrow, I'll remind you to finish this course (lesson 3) as this is crucial knowledge in today's AI age. Stay tuned!

Let's be on the right side of change! 🚀
Chris

subject: ChatGPT vs Human Coder ⚔️ Who Wins Fixing GitHub PRs
body:
Hey {User},

It's easy to fall into the belief that human roles, e.g., in software engineering, are on the verge of being replaced.

I'm guilty of prematurely announcing various job roles dead, even though they may survive another decade or so.

In defense of the more traditionalist argument that ChatGPT is overhyped, a recent Princeton paper titled “SWE-bench: Can Language Models Resolve Real-World GitHub Issues?” sheds light on the limitations of even the most advanced language models in the field of software development. 👇

[Blog] Human Software Developers vs ChatGPT – Who’s Better in Fixing GitHub Pull Requests?

As you'll learn in the blog, human developers are still superior in 96% of GitHub pull requests.

For now, we haven't seen LLMs replacing traditional software developer roles. On the contrary, we have seen legions of new developer positions opening up in prompt engineering, e.g., using the Python OpenAI API. 

Like in chess, the arrival of strong AI has led to a revival of popularity and interest in software engineering.

Let's be on the right side of change! 🚀
Chris
