subject: Best Programming Language for Bitcoin
body:
Hey {User},

At Finxter, we want to anticipate and position ourselves to benefit from change.

We all have seen the emergence of LLMs this year - while still underrated, it's old news.

The capabilities of LLMs will continue to explode with AI training costs being reduced by 70% per year, so in two years, we'll see 10x efficiency gains.

What does that imply?

Clearly, LLM-based AI agents (e.g., built with Python) will autonomously and independently move through cyberspace and participate in the cyberspace economy.

But in order to become autonomous economic agents, they need to be able to send, receive, and hold money.

They cannot easily hold USD in a bank account because they are not human.

They cannot transact with VISA because they have no bank account and they wouldn't be able to afford the ~2% tax on each transaction. If these bots used VISA, only 35 transactions would halve their money!

That's why we can see projects like LangChainBitcoin that empower LLM-based agents like Auto-GPT to participate in the economy via the Internet-native monetary system: Bitcoin.

[Blog] What is the Best Programming Language for Bitcoin?

The tl;dr is that Python is the best programming language to develop apps and bots on top of Bitcoin. Nobody really uses C++ to create apps these days. However, if you want to become a protocol developer, you'd need to learn C++.

Let's be on the right side of change! 🚀
Chris

subject: Making Money with Python
body:
Hey {User},

About 90% of the readers of the Finxter newsletter are Python developers who are interested in discussing financial matters. However, for some, this topic is considered taboo despite the amount of time they dedicate to earning money.

Large Language Models (LLMs) like ChatGPT continue to automate large parts of our economy.

To be on the right side of change, I believe, you must be an owner of scarce and desirable assets so you'll benefit from automation.

You want to own, control, and leverage productive assets to your advantage.

There are two paths to asset ownership:

(1) Build the asset yourself (e.g., creating your own company), or

(2) Acquire the asset (e.g., purchasing ownership interest in disruptive corporations like Facebook, Amazon, Tesla, Google, and Nvidia -- or buying a stake in a scarce monetary network like Bitcoin).

In both cases, money is needed. So, let's make some money?

In this article, I give you a broad overview of how to make money with Python, i.e., being in the automation industry where you are the disruptor rather than you getting disrupted:

[Blog] 55 Best Ideas to Make Money with Python

Here are some example paths to make money with Python:

  • Junior Web Developer: Employed in tech startups, they build websites using Django or Flask, earning $40,000 - $60,000 annually.
  • Python Tutor: Offering tutoring sessions as self-employed educators, they earn between $25,000 - $60,000 annually.
  • Machine Learning Engineer: Working in tech or finance sectors, they design machine learning models, with salaries ranging from $80,000 - $150,000 yearly.
  • Python Blogger/Content Creator: Generating income from ads, sponsorships, and affiliate marketing, they earn $20,000 - $300,000 annually, depending on the size of the audience. Many make nothing. A few make much more.
  • Quant Developer in Finance: Working in finance or banking, they design algorithms for trading or analysis, earning $100,000 - $240,000 yearly.
  • Startup Founder: Launching tech startups, their income is variable, potentially reaching $40,000+ monthly if successful.

There are many more career paths, some highly unconventional. Read today's Finxter article if you want to learn more and also consider joining our best-selling Finxter Freelancer Course for a detailed howto guide on building a six-figure skillset.

Let's be on the right side of change! 🚀
Chris

subject: Disruptive Innovation for Small Business Owners
body:
Hey {User},

Yesterday, I promised a guide on disruptive innovation, so here it is. Because I wanted to make it more relevant, I tailored it towards smaller startups in the tech/coding niche. Enjoy! 👇

[Blog] Disruptive Innovation - A Friendly Guide for Small Coding Startups

📈🧑‍💻 Here’s my key takeaway: (not financial advice) 🙄

It is tough to create a huge disruptive startup in a large industry. It is easier to disrupt a tiny niche.

A great strategy that I found highly profitable is focusing on a tiny niche within your career, optimizing daily, and investing your income in star businesses, i.e., disruptive innovation companies in high-growth markets (growing >10% per year) that are also market leaders.

💡 Formula: High-Growth Market + Market Leader = Getting Rich

If you're following this formula, you'd only invest your time or money in companies or opportunities that are both, in a high-growth market and leader of this market.

Bitcoin, for example, is the leader of a high-growth market (=digital store of value). Tesla, another example, is the leader of a high-growth market (=autonomous electric vehicles).

Check out the blog post for more.

Let's be on the right side of change! 🚀
Chris

subject: Role Playing with AI
body:
Hey {User},

Does the Role-Play Prompting Technique really work? What does science say? 🤔

To answer the question, I just published a new article about role-play prompting in large language models (LLMs) 🤖. A study showed this method can majorly boost accuracy in tasks.

For instance, it increased accuracy scores in realistic datasets from 53.5% to 63.8% and even 23.8% to 84.2%! 📈

And this is on top of the single-shot prompting technique of asking it to "think step by step" - another well-documented prompting trick I've already written about!

Though it's not a one-size-fits-all solution, role-playing opens up exciting possibilities for prompt engineers.

Worth checking out:

👉 [Blog] Exploring Role-Play Prompting LLMs – What Does Science Say?

Also, I'm excited to announce that we now have a WhatsApp Channel to keep you educated about LLMs, generative AI, and prompt engineering.

🔗 WhatsApp Channel Invitation (100% free): Your daily educational message right in WhatsApp!

Feel free to join us, I just opened up the channel yesterday.

Last but not least, I've tested out the Mixtral 8x7B, a new language model that's an order of magnitude faster than ChatGPT and outperforms LLaMA 2:

👉 [Blog] Mixtral 8x7B Outperforms LLaMA 2 and Beats ChatGPT in Speed by 21x to 44x!

It's amazing, blazingly fast. In the article, I'll show you how you can try it in seconds.

Be on the right side of change! 🚀

subject: How to Craft Your Own Proprietary LLM
body:
Hey {User},

Did you read yesterday's Finxter article on Tesla's breaking success on the self-driving front?

Tesla's former AI chief Andrej Karpathy (now working for OpenAI) has predicted this phenomenon he calls "Software 2.0" for years: AIs self-program through data rather than explicit instructions and algorithms.

Yes, data curation is next-level coding.

... and Mechanistic Interpretability attempts to reverse engineer the emergent algorithms self-developed by the AIs.

Here's some signal for you in our noisy tech world:

💡 The complexity of Tesla's autopilot system went down from 300,000 to 3,000 lines of code by a factor of 100 as its performance increased!

The problem of self-driving cars seems to be solved by an end-to-end neural net that transforms photons (captured by cameras) into human-level driving commands.

The magic appears through massive amounts of data thrown on massive amounts of compute; read my recent article on AI Scaling Laws.

In today's Finxter article, let's have a look at how you can leverage this mega-trend in your own small apps by using your own small (proprietary) data set to fine-tune an LLM: 👇

[Blog] Fine-Tuning GPT-3.5 Turbo – How to Craft Your Own Proprietary LLM

The blog describes the new OpenAI API feature - super simple yet powerful. Try it out!

🧑‍💻👍

Let's be on the right side of change! 🚀
Chris

subject: What’s Not Going to Change in 10 Years? (Jeff Bezos)
body:
Hey {User},

A major challenge for most people is to keep up with the rapid changes of our times. But in some instances, avoiding change may be the right strategy:

Jeff Bezos (Amazon): "I almost never get the question: ‘What’s not going to change in the next 10 years?’ And I submit to you that that [...] question is actually the more important [...] — because you can build a business strategy around the things that are stable in time."

So what doesn't change?

What can we build our business strategy and careers on amidst rapid disruptions from multiple converging fields?

Sam Altman (OpenAI): "The stuff that people cared about 50,000 years ago is likely to be the stuff people care about 100 years from now."

I did the exercise and found ten things that will remain the same - use them as foundations of your own career:

💡 [Blog] What’s Not Going to Change in 10 Years? (Jeff Bezos)

Be on the right side of change. 🚀
Chris

subject: Buy and Hold 📈
body:
Hey {User},

I love simple heuristics.

For example, the research papers I coauthored introduce painfully simple algorithms to partition graphs. I don't like complex investment "algorithms" either. What resonates with me is a simple strategy such as:

  1. Identify a small group of outstanding companies that drive change (e.g., the six largest tech stocks by marketcap)
  2. Buy them monthly in equal weights.
  3. Hold for a decade. No rebalancing - let the winners ride!

In today's Finxter article, I backtested this exact strategy:

📈 [Blog] Buy and Hold Through Change! $600 Monthly to $500K in 10 Years with Tech Stocks

The compound annual growth rate (CAGR) of this strategy was north of 20%.

If you implemented this same strategy today, you'd buy these companies:

  • Apple
  • Microsoft
  • Alphabet
  • Amazon
  • NVIDIA
  • Meta

All of them will benefit greatly from the proliferation of AI in the next decade. Personally, I'd add the seventh largest tech company, Tesla, due to its disruptive opportunity of the Tesla bot.

I bet this simple strategy will smoke the S&P 500.

🛑 No investment advice! 🛑

Be on the right side of change. 🚀
Chris

subject: Is ChatGPT greedy? I offered it a $1M tip
body:
Hey {User},

Are LLMs greedy?

Can you prompt engineer GPT-4 Turbo by offering it a tip on a perfect response?

A Twitter user suggested that offering ChatGPT a $200 tip improves model performance by 11% (even though it's impossible to actually tip ChatGPT).

Unfortunately, I couldn't find any research on this topic: Academia is slow and steady. I'm sure we'll see some papers in a couple of months.

But I couldn't wait, so I went ahead and conducted my own little study, Guerilla-style using only $7 OpenAI credits and a few hours of my time:

[Original Research] Are LLMs Greedy? An Experimental Analysis of the Tipping Prompt ($0 to $1 Million)

The initial experiments on a coding-related prompt show that tipping may offer some benefits, although the tipping amounts seem crucial.

For example, if the offered tip is tiny (e.g., $0.1), GPT-4 Turbo will perform worse.

(My scientific explanation: The model feels insulted.)

In our example, the quality "improvements" from using this prompting technique range from -27% to +57% when offering a tip of $0.1 and $1,000,000, respectively.

However, this is not published research and my research skills have become a bit rusty over the last 3-4 years. Further research using different types of prompts with ground truth is definitely needed to validate this hypothesis.*

Feel free to check out the article and share it with your friends and colleagues if you find it worthy of sharing.

If you have additional prompt ideas that allow us to measure quality easily and objectively, feel free to let me know.

Be on the right side of change! 🚀
Chris

 

*Shoutout to the few thousand academic researchers and computer science professors reading the Finxter newsletter.

subject: Everybody Underestimates This Dirty Little Skill
body:
Hey {User},

Using an LLM is only half of the equation of sound prompt engineering. The other half is passing high-quality context data into the prompts.

For example, you can use tools such as LlamaIndex to load external data into LLMs.

But how do you get this data in the first place?

The answer remains as dirty as ever: web scraping.

That's why web scraping, the skill, is in high demand. In fact, Google Trends shows that interest in web scraping is at an all-time high after growing in popularity every year since 2004!

Today's article shows how Finxter Charles used his web scraping skills to create a high-quality data set that can be used as the basis of a high-quality LLM pipeline: 👇

[Blog] How I Scraped Data From Over 16,000 Gyms from MindBodyOnline

The next step would be to pass that data into a web app using OpenAI's Embeddings API. This is the technical blueprint of many of the new startups that are popping up everywhere:

Web scraping 👉 "Proprietary" data set 👉 OpenAI Embeddings API 👉 Real-world utility

You can apply this blueprint to almost every industry - keep it simple!

Let's be on the right side of change! 🚀
Chris

One gem from the article - if you're getting featured by Upwork for the OpenAI Expert program, you can expect to make between $80 and $150 per hour. Making more or less is also possible but most featured OpenAI freelancers are in this range.

Rough math without considering taxes, fees, and tax-deductible business expenses:

  • At $80/hr: $80 x 40 hours x 4 weeks = $12,800/month
  • At $150/hr: $150 x 40 hours x 4 weeks = $24,000/month

So, depending on your current income level, this might be an attractive opportunity. Check out the blog for more info.

Now, you may wonder what skills you'd need to become a sought-after prompt engineer.

If yes, feel free to check out Emily's recent Finxter article as well:

subject: goal setting
body:
Hey {User}

If you're up to it, let's conduct an entertaining and insightful experiment in six easy steps. 👇

  • Step 1: Set a timer to 5 minutes.
  • Step 2: Start the timer.
  • Step 3: Hit "Reply" to this email so you have a blank sheet.
  • Step 4: Write down five goals you have in the categories (1) health, (2) happiness, (3) success, (4) finances, and (5) relationships.
  • Step 5: Write down up to five course ideas you'd be interested in that would help you reach your goals from the previous Step 4.
  • Step 6: Send it to me.

I will gather all ideas and ask you and the other coders in the community to vote for the next academy course from the submitted ideas.

Afterward, we will appoint one Finxter reader from the community to create the victorious course.

Either way, why not print the email you just sent to me and pin it to your office wall? Your goals should be always right in front of you.

Daily goal-setting is an easy life hack scientifically proven to improve your chances of success using various success metrics. Yet - only one in a thousand individuals actually practices it.

By committing to this practice, you can achieve significant levels of success without requiring exceptional abilities or intelligence.

Let's stay on the right side of change! 🚀
Chris

 

PS: I kindly ask you to give me a few days to respond, as my Inbox is already overflowing.

subject: Starling-7B: New Open-Source LLM
body:
Hey {User},

Elon's vision when cofounding OpenAI was to create an open-source non-profit counterweight to big tech AI.

Arguably, they have succeeded in scaling intelligence with LLM alien technology. However, many of us believe that OpenAI has failed to deliver open-source AI that is freely accessible by anybody.

Well - technological disruption works in magical ways.

While OpenAI's large language models are indeed closed-source, the performance of competing open-source models -- like Llama 2 and Claude 2 -- is growing even faster than OpenAI's.

So, indirectly and accidentally, OpenAI succeeded in providing us with open-source AI systems that are highly performant, downloadable, and freely accessible by anybody.

In today's Finxter article, let's review one of those open-source models that is also brand-new, i.e., Starling-7B:

[Blog] Starling-7B: UC Berkeley’s New Open-Source LLM

The model isn't freely downloadable yet; I suspect it's still research "under review", but I have already tried it online:

Not as good as GPT-4, of course, but better than Claude 2 in many ways.

Be on the right side of change! 🚀
Chris

subject: Top 7 GPTs Created by Finxters
body:
Hey {User},

Yesterday, I asked the community to share their own GPT creations, and I was happy to receive many submissions! 👇

[Blog] Top 7 GPTs Created by Finxters

These are the seven GPTs:

  • Abominable Snowman: Created by Matt in Denver, this GPT provides snow conditions and recommendations for ski resorts
  • Giggles Grim: Developed by Marcel, it's a pessimistic AI that cynically interprets current news
  • Floyd Corner: Bernard's creation, an AI-powered insurance expert that answers specific policy-related questions
  • Recovery Counselor: A beta-version GPT by Emir, designed to support addiction recovery with expert advice and inspirational quotes
  • AI Finxter: A GPT focusing on Python, AI, and technology, contributed by Gábor, a Finxter author
  • Dad Jokes: Jason's creation, a family-friendly comedian GPT that tells clean dad jokes, ideal for family entertainment
  • Grill Genius: Another of Jason's projects, this GPT offers assistance with BBQ recipes, grill temperatures, tips, and tricks

When I showed some of them to my wife, she asked a good question: why not use the normal ChatGPT?

Any GPT Creator has to be able to answer that question, or its creation will fail.

Three big general advantages of GPTs are that they can act more like Auto-GPT going through a multi-prompt process, access third-party APIs using "Actions", and focus on usability, branding, and extensive testing.

GPT developers must extensively test the GPT to help users go through a big or small (but well-defined) user journey or transformation.

Not all these boxes are checked by all of the seven Finxter GPTs, but trying as many as possible is worthwhile. As Jeff Bezos kept writing in his shareholder letters:

This is still day 1 for the Internet!

Let's be on the right side of change! 🚀
Chris

subject: Mass Unemployment 2.0
body:
Hey {User},

Two days ago, I shared this blog article with you and other Finxters:

🧑‍💻 [Blog] The Return of Mass Unemployment – Intelligent AI Bots, Expensive Capital, and Recession

In the email, I wrote:

"As a business owner, I'd rather hire one skilled prompt engineer than ten graphic designers."

I already expected to get some pushback here - and I did!

For example, an anonymous Finxter wrote the following:

~~~

Not just "no".  HELL no!

I would not do business with you or anyone who would do that to people. [...]

You do realize developers will be replaced the same way if we proceed down this route?

What are all these displaced people going to do. Such tools need to be shut down until this issue is figured out,

I am unsubscribing from your mailing list.  I can’t support such unethical behavior.

~~~

I understand that many feel threatened by the rapid technological acceleration and the changes that come with it.

That's why I write this daily newsletter to help you stay on the right side of change.

And, of course, anybody not feeling in alignment with our overall optimistic attitude toward technological developments should, in fact, unsubscribe from this email list immediately. No hard feelings.

Now let me make my case:

Our time on earth is limited. Many of us don't enjoy meaningless work that could be automated. It's frustrating!

And why bother? We all know that meaningful work exists that doesn't get done.

So, my general attitude towards automation is as follows:

Every valuable task that can be automated, should be automated.

Politics aside, here are two observations:

(1) Many people don't want to do the work, and
(2) More and more machines can do the work cheaply, efficiently, and without complaining.

For example, ChatGPT does an excellent job finding examples of how tech advancements impacted certain job roles:

  • Scribes and Illuminators (Post-Printing Press): Before the printing press, books were written by hand, often by monks in monasteries. The printing press made mass production of books possible, drastically reducing the need for manual scribes and illuminators who decorated manuscripts.

  • Weavers and Textile Artisans (Industrial Revolution): The invention of mechanized looms and other textile machinery during the Industrial Revolution significantly reduced the demand for handweaving, impacting artisans who had traditionally woven textiles by hand.

  • Blacksmiths (Advent of Automobiles): The widespread adoption of cars led to a decline in horse-drawn carriages, which adversely affected blacksmiths who were essential in making and repairing horse-drawn carriage components and horseshoes.

  • Lamplighters (Electric Lighting): Before electric streetlights, lamplighters were employed to light gas or oil street lamps every evening. The advent of electric lighting rendered this occupation obsolete.

  • Telegraph Operators (Telephone and Internet): With the advent of the telephone and later the internet, the need for telegraph operators, who transmitted messages using Morse code, diminished significantly.

  • Typesetters (Digital Printing and Publishing): The rise of digital printing technologies and desktop publishing software reduced the need for manual typesetters, who arranged letters for printing presses.

  • Film Photographers and Darkroom Technicians (Digital Photography): The digital photography revolution led to a decline in demand for traditional film-based photographers and darkroom technicians who developed film.

  • Travel Agents (Online Booking Platforms): The rise of online travel booking platforms has significantly reduced the need for traditional travel agents, as people can now plan and book trips themselves online.

  • Bank Tellers (Online Banking and ATMs): The introduction of ATMs and online banking services has decreased the need for as many bank tellers, as customers can perform many banking tasks themselves without visiting a branch.

  • Video Store Clerks (Streaming Services): The rise of online streaming services like Netflix and Hulu has dramatically reduced the demand for video rental stores, impacting the jobs of video store clerks.

I didn't hire a secretary to make this but paid $20/m to an AI company. Making this list would've taken me an hour or two - now it's just a few seconds.

If you're on the right side of change, you'll get attacked for using electric vehicles that drive themselves (no Uber driver!), streaming videos (no video stores!), or purchasing online (no department stores!).

"I can't support such unethical behavior."

In the end, of course, it doesn't matter.

"No force on earth can stop an idea whose time has come." - Victor Hugo

So why bother? There is no moral high ground for not using technology.

In fact, if we don't adopt new technologies, we'll die!

Adapt or die.

Be on the right side of change! 🚀
Chris

subject: Python Puzzle: Why did the programmer quit his job?
body:
Hey {User},

Q: Why did the programmer quit his job?
A: Because he didn't try enough before finally deciding to return! 😄

~~~

After that "killer" introduction (no dead threats, please), let's solve a Python puzzle! Others solve crossword puzzles on Saturday evenings. We do Python puzzles in the Finxter community! Can you solve it?👇

🐍🐍🐍

def job(quit=False):
    try:
        return 'stay'
    finally:
        if quit:
            return 'quit'

print(job())
print(job(quit=True))

🐍🐍🐍

The online version also has the correct solution and the explanation:

🧩 [App] Solve This Puzzle and Check Your Correct Answer

Happy puzzling - and have a beautiful weekend! ♥️

If you insist on honing your coding skills today, feel free to glance over this excellent blog tutorial (+video) by Nicholas:

[Blog] Python Try Except: An Illustrated Guide

Before you ask "Is learning Python still relevant today?", here's my take:

Python remains the 600-pound gorilla in the LLM and AI space. If anything, it has gained a few pounds this year.

The market value of a skilled Python developer went up significantly this year. It's all about LEVERAGE in the AI economy, and coding is the ultimate form of leverage.

Let's be on the right side of change! 🚀
Chris

body:
Hey {User},

Opinions are cheap. Everybody has one. And everybody loves sharing them.

In today's quick email I want to examine a question that has been lingering in my mind:

Is ChatGPT creative?

I wasn't particularly eager to plow through seas of "Yes because" and "No because" opinion pieces, but I wanted to read actual research papers that objectively quantify this question.

First, I was disappointed to see that not a lot of research on LLM creativity is out there. If you're a researcher, this may be an exciting underexplored avenue.

Second, I found three papers that weren't total garbage. Here's the compilation of these three papers:

If you're interested in creative work and using ChatGPT to boost your creative output, this may be a valuable read for you.

subject: 30 Tasks AI Can't Replace (Yet)
body:
Hey {User},

Large language models have scaled up intelligence.

But many activities still require a human touch.

These tasks, often perceived as dull daily routines, hold significant value precisely because they are not yet easy to automate.

A prime example of such tasks is the act of showing affection, like hugging your children or caring for your parents and family. Kindness towards others who seek your attention is another.

If somebody sends you an email with a question, it's a nudge from the world that you're not yet fully replaceable by ChatGPT.

In today's blog, I've compiled a list of "trivial" things we're still needed for - and that are not rocket science (for us):

🧑‍💻 [Blog] 30 Everyday Human Tasks AI Can’t Replace in the Foreseeable Future

Activities like holding and controlling investments, buying or renovating a house also fall into this category.

We need to apply for the loan, orchestrate human labor, find sellers and buyers, and prompt ChatGPT to spit out real estate copy.

They are not just technical transactions but involve a series of decisions and interactions that are deeply human.

One day, these tasks may be automated. But today, the Universe still wants us to do them.

To be on the right side of change, we need to appreciate the little things and be grateful for every opportunity to participate in value creation.

That's why I appreciate every single email from a Finxter community member - even though I often need some time to reply, it's great to talk to other human beings amidst all the disruption.

Be on the right side of change. 🚀
Chris

subject: 0.3 million satoshis for you?
body:
Hey {User},

Finxter reader Maria expressed her interest in a Bitcoin Lightning course specifically for coders as a future academy course in the future.

I wanted to probe the community's interest in the Bitcoin protocol first, so I came up with a fun giveaway:

We'll give away $100 in Bitcoin (341,000 Sats) in the Finxter Discord Mastermind Group within 24 hours.

How exactly does it work?

I'll post a Python puzzle revealing the public/private Bitcoin key of a wallet with $100 in Bitcoin into the #👑-mastermind channel. 

The public key will be the wallet's address. The private key will be the password that unlocks the contents of the wallets.

So to get the Sats you would have to "steal" the funds with the leaked private key using any standard wallet software of your choice.  

The first one to transfer "my" BTC with the leaked private key to their account gets it. Ready? Set. Go!

If you're already a premium member, keep checking the group. If you're not a premium member, feel free to join us. 

I'll post my private key between now and Friday, 12th of August, 18:28 UTC.

Let's stay on the right side of change! 🚀
Chris

 

PS: There's a vital takeaway here: NEVER store your private keys in the cloud or your computer. Keep them private. Not your keys, not your coins. If your keys are public, you don't own them.

A million people or so lost some of their Bitcoin in the last 12 months because they didn't own their private keys and the entity owning their private keys defrauded them or lost the funds.

subject: When Bureaucracy Eats Tech
body:
Hey {User},

She was pissed off.

I chatted with a medical doctor today, and she was frustrated, not with the usual hustle and bustle in the university clinic but with the health system itself.

The reason she's annoyed is not the patient work - overwhelming as it is.

Like many doctors, she loves healing humans and wants to do more of it.

But the world is not that simple!

Instead of saving lives by leveraging her high-value skills, 12 years in the making, she spends half of her time with repetitive and unnecessary administrative work that an entry-level Python coder or prompt engineer could easily automate.

For example, she was told to create a handwritten (!) letter for a patient today because she couldn't print it (OPSEC).

In an age where we can communicate instantly across the globe, she had to handwrite a letter for a patient because of some outdated rule. It's like having a Ferrari but being told you can only drive it in first gear.

And it's us, collectively, who pays for the under-utilized Ferrari in the first place.

A good friend (medical doctor) spends 30% of his time filling out forms because the head of his clinic doesn't want to hire an entry-level developer to create a simple data-entry app that could instantly free up half of the time from 50 doctors working in that clinic alone.

With the rise of AI, the technological solutions for many real-world problems are already out there. They need you, a curious tech enthusiast who plugs the right tech solution into the real-world system.

Not rocket science, just making the world a better place.

Leveraging AI isn't just about science and technology; it's mostly about driving tangible business results.

Companies and organizations seek developers like you who can help them integrate existing technology into their systems.

Skilled AI consultants are needed in every organization today, whether they know it or not.

By mastering AI, you can offer invaluable services, differentiate your business, and tap into lucrative opportunities.

For the technical skills needed, I've created a conceptual learning path you can follow:

[10-Step Learning Path] Python Beginner to Advanced AI Coder ⭐ New ⭐

The TLDR:

  1. Foundations of Programming: Begin with Python, the go-to language for AI and machine learning.
  2. Data Structures & Algorithms: Grasp the essentials of computational logic and data manipulation.
  3. Object-Oriented Programming: Dive deeper into software design and advanced programming concepts.
  4. Introduction to Language Models: Understand the basics of models like GPT and their applications.
  5. Web Data Extraction: Learn to gather and process data, a foundational skill for training and utilizing LLMs.
  6. Natural Language Processing: Explore text analysis, crucial for maximizing the potential of ChatGPT and other LLMs.
  7. Deep Dive into ChatGPT: Understand its architecture, capabilities, and practical applications in business.
  8. Advanced LLM Concepts: Delve into the intricacies of large language models, their training, and real-world applications.

Check out the blog post for the 10-step learning path with our training courses on the Finxter Academy.

Let's be on the right side of change! 🚀
Chris

subject: 3 Ways to Make Money with ChatGPT
body:
Hey {User},

There are many routes to making money with ChatGPT as a prompt engineer.

🔗 Blog: 3 Ways to Make Money with ChatGPT – The Good, The Bad, and The Ugly

Let's examine three, from worse to better! 👇

Route #1 - Create Massive Amounts of Garbage Content

The obvious way is to use it to create massive amounts of content.

As a Python prompt engineer, you can create a pipeline that crawls webpages, passes them as embeddings into GPT-4 Turbo with its huge context window of 128k tokens, and ask it to create articles based on the input and its own knowledge.

Then monetize these articles with ads.

However, I don't think this is the best way - it's very crowded!

And why bother? It adds little value to the world.

Because everybody is doing it, most won't make money this way.

So let's move on:

Route #2 - Create Quality Content

A much better route.

You can use AI to do research and help you obtain, analyze, and visualize data.

Code interpreter and GPTs can help you enrich your content. Use ChatGPT to fix grammar mistakes and improve clarity.

The Internet is a winner-takes-most market. In other words, increasing your content quality just a tiny bit can double your reach.

Want to double your reach again? Increase the quality of your content even more!

Mister Beast teaches us that it never ends.

Due to the winner-takes-most dynamics, investing human time in content quality pays off in the long term.

The opposite is also true: you should definitely use AI to enrich your content with unique insights or tools.

For instance, a human chess player guiding a chess AI will beat both, an expert chess player without AI, and a chess AI without guiding humans.

For that reason, AI-enriched human content is a sustainable route to leverage AI to make money and have a real positive impact.

Route #3 - Sell Your Consulting Services

Still - both routes #1 and #2 are very crowded and it takes years of daily effort just to get the foot in the door.

You need to love the game, or you won't make it through the years of unpaid work. The content creation market is brutal and if you see small success, you'll get copied very quickly.

Moreover, content creation doesn't pay off quickly - successful content creators give it their all for many years before reaching good income levels.

It's not easy. You must become an expert.

An easier route in my opinion -- higher expected value and a priori success probability -- is to help businesses integrate alien technology into their existing business systems.

The LLM paradigm shift has not yet trickled into the "normal" world. Millions of businesses still need to integrate generative AI in their workflows.

We are in year #1 of publicly available LLM APIs.

Even without considering likely improvements of the foundational models, it'll take years to connect and integrate LLMs with real world business systems.

Who Pays for AI Consultants?

Architects, financial advisors, grocery stores, software companies, restaurants, clothing stores, laundromats, bookstores, fitness centers, daycare centers -- all of them can and eventually will improve efficiency, i.e., maximize benefit/cost ratio, by integrating LLMs into their workflows.

As an exercise to train your business savvy, feel free to take a minute to come up with little ways to use generative AI and LLMs to improve each of these businesses!

Think small.

Some minor examples:

  • If you run a hair salon, can you delight your customers by using the Midjourney /merge command to experiment with personalized hair pictures of your customers?
  • If you run a small factory, can you use OpenAI's text-to-speech (TTS) library to welcome customers at the front door?
  • If you are a financial advisor, can you delight your clients by using LLMs to enrich portfolio analysis or visualize your clients' portfolios?
  • As a solar company, can you fully automate offer creation by means of a fine-tuned LLM?

AI consultants on Upwork make $100 per hour and more. Why? Because of the huge leverage they offer to normal businesses that just don't know how to do these things.

If you are such a business owner, hiring an AI consultancy for three hours could increase your customer satisfaction and revenue by 10%, 20%, or even 100%!

Who wouldn't spend a few hundred bucks on that bet?

Moreover, to reduce perceived risk and boost revenue, creative AI consultants can propose revenue-share models where local businesses don't need to pay upfront - but only an agreed-upon percentage of increased revenue after success.

In that case, the average hourly rate could be much higher, as the AI consultants would get a stake in the businesses.

Consider what I wrote a couple of emails ago:

"I'd rather hire one skilled prompt engineer than ten graphic designers"

The same would apply to 50/50 partnerships.

This opportunity is massive for anybody who wants to be on the right side of change. Collectively, there's orders of magnitude more revenue in serving businesses than in content creation.

Scalability and passivity can be obtained through creative partnerships.

For example, boosting revenue by 20% of a business making $50k/m can increase business value by $100k to $500k. Many small businesses in your local environment have these revenue levels.

And who knows, there may be a possibility to scale up the consultancy to a more scalable Saas business to take it to the next level?

Be on the right side of change! 🚀
Chris

subject: Injecting Life Energy Into LLMs
body:
Hey {User},

Peter Thiel, who was the first outside investor to foresee the potential of Facebook, and who also co-founded PayPal and Palantir, delivered the keynote speech at last year's Bitcoin conference.

During his speech, he named Bitcoin as the best contender to eventually rival the size of the equities market, predicting that it could increase in value by 100 times from the then-current price of roughly $43,000.

Today's price is $27,000, and many positive developments and network effects have been built since then.

Here's one narrative that I believe will take over mainstream media in the years to come:

BTC is permissionless, Internet-native money for billions of autonomous agents awakening in cyberspace. It becomes increasingly apparent that this new economy will be built on Bitcoin Lightning rails, i.e., "permissionless money over IP".

  • AI agents don't have access to VISA cards, nor will they pay 2% transaction fees to VISA because sending money 35x back and forth would result in a 50% monetary loss to VISA!
  • AI agents cannot create bank accounts. But they will participate in the global economy eventually. So the question is: how?
  • AI agents cannot afford to lose half their purchasing power in just 35x transactions.

They need permissionless money over IP.

The technically superior solution with the highest uptime and the solution with the strongest network effects right now is Bitcoin Lightning for micro transactions due to its decentralized, open-source, permissionless access, as well as its 24/7*365 availability, and immediate final settlement properties.

As a coder, if you want to learn how to create LLMs with access to money over IP, feel free to check out today's Finxter article:

[Blog] Injecting Life Energy Into AIs with Bitcoin, LLMs, APIs, & Lightning ⚡🤖

Also, if you'd love to recap the philosophical foundations of the emerging crypto industry, check out this interesting talk given a couple of days ago by Bitcoin OG Erik Voorhees on YouTube.

Let's be on the right side of change! 🚀
Chris

subject: The Art of Clean Code (5/10) - Premature Optimization
body:
Hey {User},

There is no Nobel Prize in computer science.

But we have something similar: The Turing Award. It's the highest distinction in computer science -- and it carries a $1M price financially supported by a well-known search giant that funds the web: Google.

A famous recipient of the Turing Award is Donald Knuth for his contributions "to the analysis of algorithms and the design of programming languages, and in particular for his contributions to the "art of computer programming" through his well-known books in a continuous series by this title."

Today's lesson follows a Turing-Award-winning idea addressed in our The Art of Clean Code chapter titled:

👉 Premature Optimization Is The Root of All Evil

Optimizing parts of a system too early can lead to unnecessary complexity and hinder overall progress. It is better to make the system work correctly and then optimize only if necessary and where it makes the most impact.

For instance, don't spend a lot of time optimizing code that is rarely used (use profiling tools!), don't add too many features to your product (MVP!), and don't worry about scaling your startup to millions of customers if you haven't served hundreds yet.

Check out today's article lesson for more!

Be on the right side of change. 🚀
Chris

subject: Garbage-In Garbage-Out
body:
Hey {User},

With the rising interest in generative AI, all of us are seeking signal in a noisy world.

Those passionate about AI understand that a model's effectiveness is only as good as its input training data. The principle of "Garbage in, Garbage out" applies here.

If you regularly consume superficial news with a negativity bias, it's easy to predict how your brain might respond to new information: with rejection, doubt, and criticism, often stemming from impulsive thinking.

I receive statements like these: "... I read that AI already becomes dumber, and it only averages all available information without producing anything new or creative ..."

If you point people to research indicating that ChatGPT ranks higher on creativity tests, they argue that the tests must be faulty. Yeah, sure they are faulty. Still, it's better to go with Occam's Razor, embrace the simple explanation, and remain open-minded in the face of change.

It may sound amusing, but many people dismiss the idea that Large Language Models (LLMs) are a disruptive force, set to multiply their impact tenfold every two years, thanks to the exponential decline of AI training costs.

The contrary to "Garbage-In Garbage-Out" also holds: if you train a model (or your brain for that matter) on high-quality data, you're much more likely to produce high-quality outputs.

Quality-In Quality-Out

So how can you cleanse your training data and, thereby, boost the performance of the AI model that is your brain?

Here are some strategies I employ:

  • Go for long walks. After a walk in nature, I always find clarity about my next step. Taking one step at a time, with a distant long-term goal in mind, simplifies life. Clarity becomes increasingly vital as the influx of low-quality information leads to confusion, brain fog, and fatigue.
  • Think slowly and take time. Many people form shallow and hasty conclusions, presenting them with undue confidence. I've learned that such quick opinions, though easy to offer, often hold little value.
  • Listen to podcasts with field experts but only on topics within their expertise; I avoid those who speak outside their domain. Don't necessarily listen on Bitcoiner's advice on food or the money tips from broke people (you may be able to leverage the powerful technique of inversion though: do the opposite).
  • Occasionally browse Twitter/X – but not too often, as it can be a time sink. Among the noise, you might find a valuable insight, but I'm cautious with social media. Better yet - avoid all social media including X.
  • Read select tech and coding newsletters. I strive to offer such a newsletter with a high signal-to-noise ratio – you be the judge.
  • Skim ArXiv and new research papers: these are often a rich source of knowledge and remain some of the highest-quality information available.
  • HackerNews is also an excellent source for straightforward news with a high signal-to-noise ratio.

This brings us to today's Finxter tutorial if you're interested in building your own HackerNews-like site:

[Blog] How I Coded a Hacker News Clone in Django

Enjoy reading! Windy greetings from Denmark!

Let's stay on the right side of change! 🚀
Chris

subject: Free LLM coder course inside (7 easy lessons)
body:
Hey {User},

I'd rather be roughly right than precisely wrong. Let's do some rough napkin math:

  • With ~30 million coders worldwide, about 0.4% of humans can code.
  • ~80% of coders have tried LLMs like ChatGPT.
  • Of those, only 10% have tried the Python OpenAI API.
  • And only 5% of those have used OpenAI API functions and embeddings.

Putting these numbers together, only 0.4% * 80% * 10% * 5% = 0.0016% understand OpenAI API functions and embeddings. And this number is likely way too optimistic.

In other words, less than one in 60,000 currently has the skills to leverage OpenAI API functions or embeddings -- when almost every business could use multiple coders with those skills.

Yet, many coders have convinced themselves that they can't join the top 1% in their fields when staying ahead of the curve may simply require some basic curiosity.

You could learn OpenAI function calls and embeddings in a day or two...

subject: no goals? get inspired inside 👉
body:
Hey {User}

Yesterday, I asked Finxters about their goals and desires to pick the next course for the Finxter Academy.

The response to the exercise blew me away, and I have received more than 200 goals from the community (see below)!

In today's email, I thought it'd be fun to bring some order into all the goals and share them with you so you may find some inspiration.

It's crucial to write down your five goals daily in a journal or on paper if you haven't already.

Goal setting is extremely important and can't be emphasized enough. Your subconscious mind is a lethal weapon for achieving goals, and it can work in your favor if you provide it with specific targets to focus on.

Next, I'll give you a categorized list of goals for inspiration. Your privacy is protected.

Health and Fitness:

Reading through this list, I realized that a short goal-setting tutorial may be needed. Here are a couple of tips that can be helpful for you to set goals effectively:

  • 🎯 Be Specific: Clearly define what you want to achieve.
  • ✅ Make it Measurable: Create a way to track your progress.
  • 💪 Ensure it's Attainable Yet Ambitious: Set stretch goals that are challenging but not overwhelming.
  • 🚀 Relevance Matters: Align your goals with your broader life or career ambitions.
  • ⏱️ Set a Time Frame: Define when you want to achieve your goal to stay motivated and accountable.

Here's one of my major goals that adheres to these principles:

Let's stay on the right side of change! 🚀

subject: xAI Grok - Elon's Reply to OpenAI
body:
Hey {User},

After all the drama between OpenAI and Elon Musk -- Elon having contributed millions to create the "non-profit" OpenAI that then turned for profit against Elon's recommendations -- Elon has launched xAI.

xAI has already gathered some first-class AI researchers, and it's not to be underestimated. Now they have released Grok, a humorous large language model that not only gives answers à la Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy but also proposes the right questions. 😉

[Blog] Elon Musk's xAI Releases a New Humorous LLM Called Grok Based on Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy

Although Grok hasn't yet reached GPT-4's performance, it has already surpassed GPT-3.5 in many benchmarks so it's a force to be reckoned with.

Why the term Grok?

Grok is a term coined by science fiction writer Robert A. Heinlein from the novel "Stranger in a Strange Land" about a human raised on Mars. From the book:

Grok means "to understand", of course, but Dr. Mahmoud, who might be termed the leading Terran expert on Martians, explains that it also means, "to drink" and "a hundred other English words, words which we think of as antithetical concepts. 'Grok' means all of these. It means 'fear', it means 'love', it means 'hate' – proper hate, for by the Martian 'map' you cannot hate anything unless you grok it, understand it so thoroughly that you merge with it and it merges with you – then you can hate it. By hating yourself. But this implies that you love it, too, and cherish it and would not have it otherwise. Then you can hate – and (I think) Martian hate is an emotion so black that the nearest human equivalent could only be called mild distaste.

Whatever the term means exactly, it won't be the last time you hear it; so much we can be sure of!

Let's be on the right side of change! 🚀
Chris

subject: Let's talk about habits
body:
Hey {User},

Here's something you already know:

Consistent habits over time compound to explosive success.

But although we already know how powerful and life-changing habits can be, we often underestimate their results. That's in the nature of compounding and exponentials.

As a result, we often don't take them as seriously as we should in the daily whirlwind.

Today's email should be nothing else than a short reminder to set up a habit tracker (e.g., Google Sheet with a simple YES/NO checker) and a habit that you know can change your life if done over a long period of time.

For example, let me suggest one habit I'm highly confident can make you rich in the next 10 years - that will help you stay on the right side of change:

One example habit would be spending one hour daily creating GPTs for the GPT Store.

In five years, the GPT Store will be much bigger than it is now - it's a high-growth industry.

Mobile app developers who have created simple apps on a daily basis since the launch of the Android App Store or Apple App Store have achieved significant success.

Say you do this for one, two, or three years: spending one hour every day to launch a GPT into the store daily.

Launching 1000 GPTs during the next 1000 days, roughly three years, will almost guarantee explosive success. The top 10 out of 1000 GPTs are likely to create value for millions of people.

Your top GPT among 1000 may reach tens of millions of people.

But the remaining 990 are still valuable because they make the few winners possible. We need the 990 to get the 10.

Habits compound.

And even if the GPT Store is not as successful, which I don't believe, you will still learn a lot of new things and stay on top of developments in a rapidly growing field.

A simple example of a powerful daily keystone habit. Of course, it's only one idea of many that will work.

Now, the action step: what's your daily habit to compound your knowledge, experience, and success in an explosive way over a long period of time?

Be on the right side of change! 🚀
Chris

subject: Transformers Crush Meteorology 10,000:1
body:
Hey {User},

Did you check the weather today?

🌞 ChatGPT: "On December 15, 2023, New York City is expected to experience a mild and dry day with highs around 50°F and lows near 36°F."

Simulation is how the magical prediction accuracy happens.

I have a lot of respect for simulation engineers. The few I know are skilled coders, reliable data scientists, Linux experts, and math wizards.

While many German simulation engineers work simulate things like noise impacts of rearview mirror designs in automotive, some of the best simulation experts forecast the weather.

If you're curious about how weather simulation works, here's a glimpse into what runs twice a day on a dedicated High Performance Cluster:

"A weather model divides the world or a region into small grid cells. Each cell is about 4 km to 40 km wide and 100 m to 2 km high. Our models contain 60 vertical atmospheric layers and reach deep into the stratosphere up to 60 km, which corresponds to pressure of 10-25 hPa. The weather is simulated by solving complex mathematical equations between all grid cells every few seconds. The computed values of weather variables, such as temperature, wind speed or cloudiness are stored every hour."

Sounds complex, doesn't it? It's also a lot of computational work!

Couldn't we just throw AI at the problem, i.e., training the model once and using inference twice a day to predict the weather?

Training may be expensive, but inference is very cheap.

Yes, we can.

In a groundbreaking new Nature paper, a group of Huawei researchers show how it's done:

🌧️ [Article] AI Weather Model BEATS Meteorologists – Higher Accuracy But 10,000x Faster!

Not only was this the first time a Chinese tech company has managed to publish a paper in Nature without external coauthors, but it was also the first time an AI-based model had beaten the state-of-the-art, world's best weather simulation benchmark!

When visiting computer science conferences ten years ago, my colleagues and I observed that machine learning was about to eat every discipline in computer science.

Today, transformers eat everything in and outside computer science - by successfully deploying the foundational encoder/decoder deep learning architecture. 

🍃 "Pangu-Weather is the first AI prediction model to demonstrate higher precision than traditional numerical weather forecast methods. The model allows a 10,000x improvement in prediction speed, reducing global weather prediction time to just seconds."

Check out the article for more!

Be on the right side of change! 🚀
Chris

 

PS: Ben Fox (CEO Shepherd) invited me to share my three favorite books in 2023. Feel free to check them out here.

subject: Why OpenAI won't be the next Google
body:
Hey {User},

Here's a fun story I recently read: 👩‍🦳🚗

A wealthy woman goes to a new bank in downtown San Francisco.

She meets with a loan officer and asks to borrow $10,000.

The banker asks, "What's the money for?"

"It's for a three-week vacation to Vancouver," she replied.

Banker: "What kind of security can you give us for the loan?"

Woman: "How about my new Rolls Royce? It's outside. I'll leave it with you. That'll more than cover the $10,000."

Banker: "Yeah, that's more than enough security."

After her vacation, the woman returns to the bank. She meets with the same loan officer and repays the $10,000 plus the $49 in interest.

As she's about to leave, the banker asks, "You're a wealthy woman. Why borrow money for a trip?"

The woman smiles, then replies, "Where else in San Francisco can I safely park a $350,000 Rolls for two weeks for only $69?"

~~~

It wouldn't surprise me if the woman's skill of thinking outside the box, in a first-principle, interdisciplinary way, was how she became wealthy in the first place.

The woman is an intelligent user of the system that leverages the system in creative ways to maximize value.

With the rise of LLMs, this skill of thinking outside the box has become invaluable.

Infrastructure vs Application: Who got richer, the founders of AT&T or Google?

Similarly, the generative AI revolution will create far more value for intelligent (=street smart) users of the models that create higher-level services as compared to the providers of the model infrastructure.

For example, my bet is on Tesla with its AI apps like self-driving and humanoid bots, rather than NVidia as the provider of AI infrastructure such as chips and AI-training-as-a-service.

Infrastructure tends to become commoditized over time.

Startup.ai companies like Character.ai using LLM tools like Langchain will create far more relative value compared to infrastructure companies such as OpenAI.

Both AI application and AI infrastructure businesses may grow substantially. But the outsized gains will be made by the AI application businesses where owners think in interdisciplinary ways to create apps that actually bridge the new technologies into the real world.

Discovering LLMs (Simon Willison calls it "Alien technology") is like the discovery of electricity.

Now, more than 100 years after Nikola Tesla, Thomas Edison, and others popularized the use of electricity, we're still developing applications on top of it - such as the Internet, Bitcoin, or even LLMs.

And we're already developing new applications on top of Bitcoin and LLMs. Progress often happens layer after layer after layer. One of the new base layers of humanity is infinitely scalable intelligence.

For instance, we can now access powerful proprietary LLMs via API (e.g., GPT-4-32k) or offline, free, and open-source LLMs like Llama 2 or others:

  • MPT-7B: A Free Open-Source Large Language Model (LLM)
  • The Open-Source Ecosystem Outruns Tech Giants: A Shift in AI Landscape

The question now becomes how to integrate those models into real-world applications.

Let me be blunt: Don't waste your time trying to figure out the math and theory of AI if you're not already an AI researcher and enthusiast. Instead, focus on using LLMs in your particular area of expertise.

For example, if you're working in packaging 😉, try fine-tuning a GPT-3.5 model to handle common packaging queries in your business, possibly reducing customer service overhead by 10%. 

Or, if you're working in game design, can you integrate the most popular personas from character.ai into your RPCs to make your game world truly rich in social experience?

These low-hanging fruits are everywhere now - ripe for the taking. And you don't need to be an AI professor, either. Just be a curious and playful user of the new tech.

You're just one intelligent prompt away from changing the world. 🤯

TL;DR: Moving forward, the application layer of generative AI will grow even faster than AI infrastructure service providers. Think small and apply LLMs to specific problems you face daily, rather than getting lost in AI mega visions.

Let's be on the right side of change! 🚀
Chris

subject: A Short Primer on AI Scaling Laws
body:
Hey {User},

The AI scaling laws could be the biggest finding in computer science since Moore’s Law was introduced. 📈

[Blog] AI Scaling Laws – A Short Primer

In my opinion, these laws haven’t gotten the attention they deserve (yet), even though they could show a clear way to make considerable improvements in artificial intelligence.

This could change every industry in the world, and it’s a big deal. Here are three reasons why I believe the AI Scaling Laws are as important as Moore's Law: 👇

  • Accelerating Technological Advancements: The scaling laws in AI could lead to rapid advancements in AI technologies, enabling breakthroughs in fields like natural language processing and robotics, much like Moore's Law did for computer chips.
  • Economic Growth and Disruption: Just as Moore's Law drove economic growth in the tech industry, the scaling laws in AI could lead to significant economic growth and disruption across various industries, as AI technologies automate tasks and create new business models.
  • Societal Impact: Similar to the societal impact of Moore's Law, the scaling laws in AI could have a profound effect on society, as AI technologies become more integrated into our daily lives, improving areas like healthcare and education.

Check out 🔗 today's Finxter article on AI Scaling Laws.

Let's stay on the right side of change! 🚀

subject: Is Messi the Goat? A Python Puzzle
body:
Hey {User},

Watching Messi videos with my son has revitalized my love for soccer.

(And I wonder if creating "Best X Messi Goals" videos would've been the better growth strategy for the Finxter Youtube channel 😅⚽ given that many of these videos get tens of millions of views.)

So here's a new Finxter puzzle for you - can you solve it?

 

messi_goals = 30
ronaldo_goals = 25
neymar_goals = 15

if (messi_goals > ronaldo_goals
    or ronaldo_goals > neymar_goals
    and messi_goals + neymar_goals < ronaldo_goals * 2):
    result = "Messi = GOAT"
elif (neymar_goals + ronaldo_goals < messi_goals * 2
      and messi_goals - ronaldo_goals < neymar_goals):
    result = "Messi goat"
else:
    result = "Messi"

print(result)

You can check the result and explanation on the Finxter puzzle app here.

Happy puzzling! 🚀
Chris

 

PS: Allow me to share an observation with you.

Writing about Bitcoin now during the bear market (if you can still call it that) gives very few positive replies from the community compared to the usual AI and LLM topics.

But I'm confident that writing about Bitcoin tech in a year or two, possibly during a bull market, will generate a lot of positive replies in the community.

Unfortunately, as a content creator, my incentive is to always focus on the current hot topic. However, this doesn't serve you optimally - so I will keep writing about Bitcoin from time to time, even though I know that many will ignore this groundbreaking distributed open-source monetary system (for now).

subject: AI COMPUTE MOONS 🧑‍🚀
body:
Hey {User},

A few days ago, I sent you a highly speculative article on rumors about OpenAI's breakthrough technology called Q*. I admitted that the information was very thin.

But in a fresh exclusive with The Verge, Sam Altman dropped the following bombshell:

  • Interviewer: The reports about the Q* model breakthrough that you all recently made, what’s going on there?
  • Sam Altman: No particular comment on that unfortunate leak. But what we have been saying — two weeks ago, what we are saying today, what we’ve been saying a year ago, what we were saying earlier on — is that we expect progress in this technology to continue to be rapid and also that we expect to continue to work very hard to figure out how to make it safe and beneficial.

In my logic: If Sam calls it a leak, it must be real. (?)

Diving deeper into the topic, I found the following interesting nugget:

"The [...] breakthrough allowed OpenAI to overcome limitations on obtaining enough high-quality data to train new models [...] The research involved using computer-generated [data], rather than real-world data like text or images pulled from the internet, to train new models. That appears to be a reference to the idea of training algorithms with so-called synthetic training data, which has emerged as a way to train more powerful AI models." -- Wired

Like Tesla's new end-to-end full-self-driving (FSD) system, synthetic data is now being used by OpenAI to train neural nets!

I share this with you because I believe the following take is not well-understood by the general public:

  • The AI Scaling Laws suggest we have not reached saturation in performance - all we need to do is throw more compute and more data on the problem.
  • Many argue that data is the limiting factor - e.g., in humanoid robotics, we don't have a lot of real-world data.
  • However, if we can effectively train models on synthetic data, we've mitigated this bottleneck!

We're already seeing a double-digit percentage productivity improvement for our economy due to LLMs. This trend is sustainable for at least a couple of years. Maybe decades!

Have a look at this research result in a recent first-class paper "GPTs are GPTs: An Early Look at the Labor Market Impact Potential of Large Language Models":

🧑‍💻 "Our findings reveal that around 80% of the U.S. workforce could have at least 10% of their work tasks affected by the introduction of LLMs, while approximately 19% of workers may see at least 50% of their tasks impacted. [...]"

Another big takeaway is this: when synthetic data is an effective option, the bottleneck for AI will be compute. Singularity will take our hunger for compute to the moon.

10x, 100x, 1000x of demand for AI compute in a few years wouldn't surprise me in the least.

Bullish for AI compute providers like NVDA, AMZN, and TSLA!

Be on the right side of change! 🚀
Chris

 

PS: The winner of the Finxter GPT Creator contest is Julian's Eco Chef GPT.

In Julian's words:

"Eco Chef is a GPT to analyze the environmental impact of food recipes, with a focus on providing CO2 equivalent (CO2E) values for every ingredient in the recipe. You can also chat about the environmental impact of individual ingredients.

It primarily sources environmental impact data from https://ourworldindata.org/environmental-impacts-of-food.

Users can provide a recipe URL or ask about specific ingredients. Eco Chef will detail the CO2E for each ingredient, alongside brief notes on emissions, water usage, and land use.

The GPT aims to inform users about sustainable diets with concise, clear, and educational responses, adapted to each conversation's context."

🔗 Link to GPT: https://chat.openai.com/g/g-4P2WxsUzq-eco-chef

Congrats to Finxter member Julian winning a $100 Amazon voucher for his amazing work!

subject: 16 personality types for tech enthusiats
body:
Hey {User},

Management consultant Peter Drucker hammered it in my brain:

You. Can. Only. Perform. From. Your. STRENGTHS.

Roughly one hundred million (!) people have taken the Myers and Briggs personality test. The 16personalities website (not affiliated) is one of the most viral websites out there.

tl;dr: You answer a couple of questions and the test assigns one of 16 different personalities to you based on the following four dimensions:

  1. Extraversion (E) vs. Introversion (I): Where do you direct your energy? Outwardly towards people and activities or inwardly towards thoughts and ideas.
  2. Sensing (S) vs. Intuition (N): How do you prefer to take in information? Through direct and concrete facts or by interpreting and adding meaning.
  3. Thinking (T) vs. Feeling (F): How do you prefer to make decisions? Based on logic and consistency or based on the people and special circumstances.
  4. Judging (J) vs. Perceiving (P): What's your preference when dealing with the outside world? With a planned and organized approach or a more flexible and spontaneous approach.

I found the test to be very robust. For example, no matter how often I repeat the test - I've done it at least a dozen times over the years - it always gives me INFJ (Advocate).

They may be right: I feel awful writing about this; the test lists as one of my weaknesses to being "reluctant to open up".

Anyways, just for fun I've written a small online tool where you can put in your personality type and it provides you with a possible career path in tech (tech enthusiasts only!).

[Online Tool] What’s Your Career Path Based on Myers-Briggs’ 16 Personalities?

The "recommendation" is crude so don't take it too seriously. But if only ten from 150,000 Finxters decide to adjust their career paths towards greater authenticity, nothing would make me happier and the small effort was well-spent.

Life is too short to do meaningless work that doesn't suit your personality, especially with the rise of LLMs and AGI.

Let's be on the right side of change! 🚀
Chris

body:

subject: What are embeddings in OpenAI?
body:
Hey {User}

Many (even sophisticated) OpenAI and Python API users don't understand embeddings.

I think this is a huge miss - instead of feeding huge amounts of textual contents into the model as context, they should use embeddings, i.e., vector databases.

[Blog] What Are Embeddings in OpenAI? 🔢

Embeddings, in the context of OpenAI, are numerical representations of textual or code-based information. They convert concepts into number sequences, which enables computers to comprehend the relationships between these concepts more easily.

OpenAI’s embedding models, such as text-embedding-ada-002, have been designed to outperform other top models in various standard benchmarks, including a 20% relative improvement in code search performance.

💡 Principle

You should know that isn't proprietary to OpenAI, but rather a broadly recognized principle within the machine learning field.

In a nutshell, when someone talks about "computing the embedding of a text", they're essentially converting that text into a unique numerical form. However, this isn't just any number - it's a special kind of number that allows arithmetic operations to be conducted with words or phrases, a task at which computers excel.

🧒 Child + ⏲️ Time = ?

As an example, using embeddings, you could mathematically express something like "child" + "time" equating to "adult" or "queen" minus "female" resulting in "king".

I saw this example in a Reddit threat - lovely isn't it?

Another handy feature of these numbers is that you can use them to group alike words together. For instance, "dog" and "puppy" would have numbers that are relatively close to each other, but significantly distant from "submarine".

🔍 Embeddings - Used for Search

For users of Language Learning Models (LLMs) like ChatGPT, embeddings are typically leveraged for search operations. Bear in mind that LLMs have finite space for the input and output, often referred to as the context window, meaning you can't process an entire book, for example.

If you wanted to extract information about the book, you'd divide it into smaller sections that can fit within the context window, and then you'd follow these steps:

1. Compute the embedding for each section.
2. Once you've calculated the "number" (embedding) for each section, take the user prompt and compute its embedding.
3. Next, compare the user embedding to the book section embeddings and identify the closest one. Since these are numerical values, you can use a mathematical function to determine their proximity (cosine distance is recommended by OpenAI).
4. Now, you can pass the question to GPT, accompanied by the relevant section that you've just identified.

This procedure is extremely useful and versatile, and can be implemented for various data sources, including emails in your inbox, documents on your drive, or even Amazon reviews.

I hope this explanation clarifies the concept for you!

🚀 What's Next?

Stay tuned for our upcoming emails on LLMs and exciting new tech developments. 🧑‍💻👩‍💻

And if you haven't already, check out our newly-launched course on advanced prompt engineering (e.g., using embeddings) on the Finxter Academy:

[Academy] Prompt Engineering with Python and OpenAI

To your success! 🚀
Chris

subject: Cross-Species Cooperation: Uniting Humans and Embodied AI through English Language
body:
Hey {User}

I'm a big Optimus (aka. "Tesla Humanoid Bot") fan.

With Optimus and LLMs the cost of labor is on a declining cost curve. A couple of months ago I shared my learnings on declining cost curves:

AI training costs fall by 70% per year!

These declining cost curves are incredibly robust - as we all witnessed in the form of Moore's Law during the last couple of decades.

Already we've seen a 10,000x reduction in the costs of intelligence. And we're just getting started.

See how Tesla will scale up its AI training during the next few years:

So we're seeing the beginning of a 100x explosion in AI and robotics in slow motion.

Open-source developers, researchers, and companies all over the world scale up their efforts to make this happen.

In today's email, let's dive into a recent robotics paper from MIT and IBM Watson that I just finished reading:

[Blog] Cross-Species Cooperation: Uniting Humans and Embodied AI through English Language

The TLDR of this paper is that, surprisingly, an efficient middle-ground API for the collaboration of humans and robots (e.g., Tesla bots, OpenAI bots, Boston Dynamic bots, Open-source LLM bots) may very well be --- wait for it --- natural language.

Not 1s and 0s. Not Python code. No function calls. Just messy and ambiguous English.

The researchers suggest a unique approach to LLM planning and natural language collaboration to foster cross-species cooperation towards a common goal.

Exciting to see the emergence of cyber-biological meta organisms collaborating towards bigger goals in an autonomous and decentralized manner.

We are at the brink of an era of great abundance.

To your success! 🚀

subject: Can you solve this Python puzzle? (Intermediate Level)
body:
Hey {User},

Today let's have a fun Python puzzle with an in-built health tip. 🍎 Can you solve it?

food_items = [
    ['apple', 'fruit'],
    ['broccoli', 'vegetable'],
    ['banana', 'fruit'],
    ['carrot', 'vegetable'],
    ['cake', 'dessert'],
    ['chicken', 'meat']
]

fruits = [item[0] for item in food_items if item[1] == 'fruit']
health_tip = f"Eat more {', '.join(fruits[:-1])} and {fruits[-1]} for better health!"

print(health_tip)
# (A) Eat more apple, banana and carrot for better health!
# (B) Eat more apple and banana for better health!
# (C) Eat more broccoli, carrot and chicken for better health!
# (D) Eat more apple, banana and broccoli for better health!

As always, feel free to solve this puzzle online and track your skills on the Finxter website.

These small Python games are a great way to boost your coding skills and as I pointed out in my previous two emails, understanding Python code is more important than ever!

subject: LlamaIndex - What the Fuzz
body:
Hey {User},

Imagine Albert Einstein is standing before you, ready to help you out.

Now if you ask Einstein a generic question like "How can I stay relevant in today's world?", you'll get a generic answer.

Even Einstein's high-IQ brain needs relevant and fresh information about your personal situation and the current context to give you a helpful answer.

Human Prompting 101

If you want to be a good human "prompter", you'll need to carefully inject recent and relevant context to obtain the best answers from the biological brains.

The same holds for prompting artificial brains like large language models (LLMs): if you prompt an LLM with the right context data, you'll get vastly better results.

But how to do it with Python?

Enter LlamaIndex.

Think of it as a helper library that allows you to feed ChatGPT with just the right context from myriads of data sources in real-time—everything the LLM needs to extract meaningful insights from data.

Just as scholars need both their inherent knowledge and the latest research to provide the best answers, ChatGPT requires both its training and fresh data from LlamaIndex.

Missing either the brain (e.g., ChatGPT) or the context (e.g., using LlamaIndex) would be like trying to solve a puzzle with half the pieces. The magic truly happens when they come together:

High-Quality Data + High-IQ Brain

In today's Finxter article, I'll give you a big-picture overview of LlamaIndex because I found this was missing in their docs:

🦙 [Blog] LlamaIndex – What the Fuzz?

Now moving to a different Python library I found fascinating: Python's free weather API that allows you to plot historical weather data from your hometown:

🐍 [Blog] Python Code for Getting Historical Weather Data

Just for fun, you could even combine both:

Create a simple weather assistant chatbot based on LLM tech (e.g., GPT-3.5-Turbo) and feed it historical weather data from the API to provide users with all kinds of weather information, even weather-, seasonal- and location-based experience recommendations, in natural language.

LlamaIndex is powerful, you can plug any data source into any LLM! 🤯

subject: 🐍 Python Puzzles Challenge: Test Your Skills! 🧠
body:
Hey {User},

Let's do some work on labor day to sharpen your body and mind. 💪

Can you solve all three "Python Health Puzzles" (beginner, intermediate, expert) in 5 minutes or less?

I've also included a link for each puzzle, ensuring a user-friendly experience, especially on mobile where the email formatting might disrupt readability.

1. Healthy Habits 🚶‍♂️

exercise_recommendations = "Walk 30 minutes daily. Drink 8 glasses of water. Sleep 7-9 hours nightly."
benefit = exercise_recommendations.split(".")[0]
print(benefit)

🔗 Test Your Solution & See Explanation

 

2. Vitamin Boost 🍇

fruits = ["apple", "banana", "cherry", "date", "elderberry"]
vitamin_c_content = [5, 10, 7, 2, 60]  # in mg per 100g
high_vitamin_c_fruits = [fruit for fruit, content in zip(fruits, vitamin_c_content) if content > 10]
print(high_vitamin_c_fruits)

🔗 Test Your Solution & See Explanation

 

3. Mind and Body Balance 🧘‍♀️

activities = ["running", "swimming", "yoga", "cycling", "meditation"]
minutes_spent = [40, 30, 60, 20, 15]
recommended = [activity for activity, minutes in zip(activities, minutes_spent) if (activity == "meditation" and minutes >= 10) or (activity != "meditation" and minutes >= 30)]
print(recommended)

🔗 Test Your Solution & See Explanation

Have fun with the puzzles and enjoy the rest of your day! ♥️

Let's be on the right side of change! 🚀
Chris

A new race is emerging at exponential speed.

subject: Bye Bye Elites 👋 ChatGPT Levels the Playing Field in Search Performance and UX vs Google Search
body:
Hey {User}

I just released a new tutorial on a brand-new paper (published today) that shows the difference in performance and user experience of ChatGPT vs Google:

[Research] Bye Bye Elites 👋 ChatGPT Levels the Playing Field in Search Performance and UX vs Google Search

TLDR:
(1) Using ChatGPT outperforms using Google across study groups
(2) ChatGPT levels the playing field, i.e., PhDs don't outperform high-schoolers

Fascinating stuff considering there are a couple of low-hanging fruits for ChatGPT, whereas Google Search is already optimized in every way imaginable. Reminds me of the electric vehicle space compared to OEMs.

Some low-hanging fruits:

  • Improve speed by 10x so ChatGPT will feel much more intuitive and responsive.
  • Integrate with many apps and browsers (e.g., using plugins and functions) so ChatGPT will be 10x more useful.
  • Improve the chatbot performance (e.g., integrating real-time data) so ChatGPT output quality will increase by 10x.
  • Add multi-modality so ChatGPT input & output can be images, videos, audio.

Together, these and other improvements can easily result in multiple orders of magnitude of performance improvement. ChatGPT will not only be faster and produce better quality results but also feel much more natural.

I know many Googlers are reading this newsletter and hope that research papers like these can escalate the urgency of pushing their UX to the next level - I would prefer not to see Google falling for the innovator's dilemma.

If you're still interested in some fascinating new research papers, check out the following fresh paper showing how Microsoft Research has applied ChatGPT to robotics:

[Research] ChatGPT Breaks New Ground in Robotics! This New Microsoft Research Shows How

To your success! 🚀
Chris
