subject: Smart Contracts on Bitcoin w/o Hard Fork - Dream or True?
body:
Hey {User},

I remember talking to a few colleagues about Bitcoin back in 2016.

As distributed systems researchers, we were genuinely excited about the tech. What fascinated us was that it was now possible in a practical, real-world system to find a majority consensus that tolerates a minority of nodes failing or even trying to hack the system.

One of us mentioned that Bitcoin could be a good investment, but most rejected the idea. Bitcoin - too obvious, old-school tech, and overhyped. A massive bull run followed, increasing BTC's price by more than 30x.

Opportunity often hides in plain sight. Today, most people, even techies, reject Bitcoin. I believe they will miss a similar bull run in the years to come.

Today, we are deep in the bear market. The opening rates of all my Bitcoin emails are low. Of course, this will change in the upcoming bull market. But today, the early majority (~34%), late majority (~34%), and laggards (16%) don't care about Bitcoin.

Yet - bullish news is building up:

Upcoming demand shock from the Bitcoin ETF, regulatory clarity, intangible accounting rule change, increasing liquidity in global financial markets, a record low of BTC supply on exchanges, federal chaumian mints, nation state mining announcements, Lightning payments for LLM agents, and now this. 👇

[News Article] BitVM – Smart Contracts on Bitcoin Without Hard Fork

Under the radar of those who haven't followed the space closely during the last few years, massive multi-party network effects from developers, miners, politicians, citizens, and HODLers have been accumulated.

This new BitVM paper has opened up another universe for adopting "money over IP". If you know Internet culture, you've read about protocol wars in the 1970s. The open-source, more decentralized protocol TCP/IP has won against closed-source protocols pushed by more centralized entities like Cisco.

The Internet economy, a rapidly growing portion of global trade, will be built on an Internet-native "money over IP" protocol. The transition is inevitable. What technology will win?

Well, the answer is the same as in 2016: the largest, open-source, decentralized "money over IP" protocol with the biggest network effects. We shouldn't reject it only because it seems obvious.

Check out the new Finxter article to learn more about the most recent breakthrough!

Let's be on the right side of change! 🚀
Chris

subject: The Chain-of-Verification Prompting Tactic
body:
Hey {User},

Just stumbled on this new prompting technique developed by some researchers from Meta AI and ETH Zurich: 👇

[Blog] Chain-of-Verification: This Novel Prompting Technique Fights Hallucinations in LLMs

The idea is simple and makes sense from first-principles thinking. The researchers are top-notch. So allow me to recap the 4-step prompting strategy here quickly:

  1. Drafting an Initial Response: The language model drafts an initial response based on the input query.
  2. Planning Verification Questions: The language model then devises verification questions to fact-check its draft.
  3. Answering Verification Questions: These questions are answered independently to avoid bias.
  4. Generating a Final Verified Response: Utilizing the answers, the model refines its initial draft and generates a final, more accurate response.

As prompt engineers, we should build a mental library of these prompting strategies. You never know if or when you'll come up with that million-dollar prompt that disrupts an industry!

I believe the immediate future of high-performant LLMs will be multi-model, multi-modal systems where multiple AIs or AI agents work together in a dynamic pipeline of self-promptings to generate highly enriched answers that outperform the prompting results of individual models.

That is — at least until the one AGI model that rules them all rises from the mountains of new AI research published daily. 🤖

Let's be on the right side of change! 🚀
Chris

subject: Reverse Engineer Plots with Bard
body:
Hey {User}

Consider the following scenario I've often encountered as a coder:

Say you read a research paper, article, or book and you wonder how a certain plot was made.

You cannot really use StackOverflow or even Google search for that...

When encountering this exact problem today, it became apparent to me that there may be a simple solution:

I wondered if Google Bard can reverse engineer simple Python plots?!

📈 My Input: A screenshot of a plot (e.g., taken from a paper or report)

🤖 Bard Output: Python Matplotlib code

If you think about it, this is an insanely valuable use case for data scientists! 🤯 So I've written a short blog guide on it:

👉 Three examples: Towards Reverse Engineering Matplotlib Code From Images

I’m very impressed with Google Bard’s capabilities, and I’m sure they will grow significantly over the next couple of months.

Google Bard can already match the capabilities of an entry-level data scientist. You can already pass simple plots and let it reverse-engineer the code that generated those plots.

Soon you’ll be able to pass arbitrary plot screenshots into it and let it generate the code for you. This is six-figure-per-year work currently done by advanced data scientists.

When I was still a researcher at University, I’d have done almost everything for such a tool — given that most research papers live and die by the high-quality plots they generate and most researchers and data scientists spend huge amounts of time figuring out how others have generated their stunning-looking plots.

Check it out and integrate this simple 3-minute trick into your daily practice to save hours of plotting research in the future.

To your success! 🚀
Chris

 

PS: If you run a tech startup or AI company, you seek more visibility for your product, or you want to find top talent in the AI, programming, and tech space, feel free to check out the Finxter newsletter sponsorship we have just launched.

subject: Passing Ten Papers In One Prompt
body:
Hey {User}

Have you already checked out the new large language model (LLM) everybody's talking about?

Today I spent a few hours researching Claude 2, the newly-launched LLM from Anthropic. (No worries if you don't know them - I didn't.)

Like ChatGPT, it can pass many human-centric tests such as grade school math problem solving, Q&A on very long stories, answering science questions, or reading comprehension. And it beats most humans.

And like ChatGPT, Claude 2 can even pass the bar (lawyer) and the USMLE test (medicine).

But unlike ChatGPT and most other open-source models, it can process 200k token context data!! 🤯

You can get a quick overview on the Finxter blog:

🔗 [Blog] Claude 2 LLM Reads Ten Papers in One Prompt with Massive 200k Token Context

Currently, US citizens can already try it out. You can upload your PDFs and do all the fun stuff the rest of the world (*cough* Germany) cannot access yet (*cough* without VPN).

Now you may wonder - is a 200k token (~150k words) context window large?

An average novel is around 80,000 to 100,000 words.

So, 150,000 words would be equivalent to a long novel or perhaps a trilogy of shorter novels. For example, “Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix” by J.K. Rowling is over 257,000 words.

My doctoral thesis was only 57k so you could load multiple Ph.D. theses into a single prompt.

This is insane. And I don't understand why so many people try to tamper my excitement - don't they get exponentials?

In fact, most humans would struggle if I handed them two Ph.D. theses and asked them to write a detailed comparison. But all of this could be done in a single 200k context window!

Check out the blog, charts, and Claude 2 model and stay tuned for tomorrow's email where I'll show you another great tech achievement.

To your success! 🚀
Chris

subject: Early signs of singularity? 3 coping tips inside
body:
Hey {User},

Singularity is a point in time where technological growth becomes uncontrollable and irreversible resulting in unforeseeable changes to human civilization.

Many first-class computer scientists have expressed their support of the thesis that "singularity is near".

Ray Kurzweil predicts paradigm shifts will become increasingly common, leading to "technological change so rapid and profound it represents a rupture in the fabric of human history". In fact, Kurzweil predicted human-level AI by 2029 which seems too conservative to me given the recent advancements in LLM technology.

John von Neumann argues that the "ever-accelerating progress of technology and changes in the mode of human life gives the appearance of approaching some essential singularity in the history of the race beyond which human affairs, as we know them, could not continue."

Irving Good who worked with Alan Turing on Bayesian statistics and cryptography speculated that an intelligence explosion will happen as follows: "Let an ultra-intelligent machine be defined as a machine that can far surpass all the intellectual activities of any man however clever. Since the design of machines is one of these intellectual activities, an ultra-intelligent machine could design even better machines; there would then unquestionably be an 'intelligence explosion', and the intelligence of man would be left far behind."

Stephen Hawking worried that "The development of full artificial intelligence could spell the end of the human race. It would take off on its own, and re-design itself at an ever-increasing rate. Humans, who are limited by slow biological evolution, couldn't compete, and would be superseded."

Okay, I'm more optimistic. Positive change in the AI space is not slowing down. It accelerates. For instance, here are some news headlines that I collected during the last couple of days:

  • Tesla's Optimus robot can now sort objects autonomously using an end-to-end neural network system similar to the groundbreaking full self-driving system presented earlier this month.
  • Amazon is investing up to $4 billion in Anthropic.
  • ChatGPT is getting multi-modal capabilities, allowing users to speak to the model, have it speak back, and upload images for questions.
  • Spotify introduces AI-powered voice translation for podcasts using OpenAI's Whisper, maintaining the original voice in translations.
  • ChatGPT helps diagnose tethered cord syndrome in a boy, highlighting AI's potential in medical applications.
  • OpenAI announces DALL-E 3 with enhanced features and integration with ChatGPT.
  • Google's Bard chatbot now offers a "double-check" feature to enhance accuracy and accountability.

In today's email, I want to share three "coping mechanisms" to help you thrive in the upcoming decades.

✅ First, you can be certain about one thing: change.

Stay open-minded, set aside daily time to learn, apply, and play with new technologies such as those mentioned above.

To help you stay on the right side of change, we'll be here with Finxter during the next decade or so with small daily doses of tech knowledge.

✅ Second, you strive to be an owner not merely a user of new technologies.

Technological disruption will create an abundance of many things but it will inherently flow to the owners of the technology first.

Investing in scarce desirable assets will remain a great idea.

The scarcest and most desirable asset is Bitcoin. The infinity of AI meets the scarcity of Bitcoin. Supply is fixed and demand will explode so you figure out my price expectations for BTC: 📈

✅ Third, focus on love and lasting relationships instead of work.

Much of the work you're doing today will be done by robots tomorrow. Why bother sacrificing quality time with your family just so you can cram in a little bit of additional work?

Just use LLMs for automation, cut your work time by half, and let the machines do your job better than you could. A single intelligent prompt you create at the right time and the right location could accomplish more than a lifetime of unskilled labor.

Again focus on being an owner and early user of new tech. Don't focus on being a working bee. There's little reward for being a hard worker in a fully automated factory. But there is a significant reward for being the owner and, possibly, designer of this same factory.

Let's be on the right side of change! 🚀
Chris

subject: LLM in a Flash
body:
Hey {User},

Alien technology is about to be put in every device and every imaginable object.

The world around us is waking up, starting to sense, even understand the environment, and react to subtle changes. Intelligence is about to become ubiquitous and ambient, and we can only guess how much an intelligent environment will disrupt the world we know.

Now this:

⚡ [Blog] LLM in a Flash – Apple’s Attempt to Inject Intelligence Into the Edge

Apple researchers found a way to use less memory by storing LLMs on a different kind of memory (flash memory, that’s why the paper's name) and only moving it to the main memory (DRAM) when needed.

💡 Action step: Can you start a small home-based business integrating a Raspberry Pi with a small local LLM (no WiFi!) and an everyday object to make it aware of its surroundings?

body:
Hey {User},

The future of work is uncertain and our careers, as we know them, are at risk of disruption.

We all feel it.

Here's what I struggle with these days: I've interwoven too much of my self-worth and identity with my perceived contribution to society. Machines doing more and more of that heavy lifting keeps undermining my feeling of self-worth:

Why am I here?

Millions of Finxters struggle with the same question, consciously or subconsciously.

So, allow me to make explicit what is often missed due to it being too obvious:

⭐ Our job roles should not be the source of our self-esteem or worthiness. ⭐

Associating our self-worth with our work is a precarious position to be in, as it makes us vulnerable to external changes. If our self-worth is too deeply intertwined with our job, any threat to that job can feel like a personal attack, leading us to either resist change or feel lost and devalued when change is inevitable.

Consider retirement as an example.

It's often observed that people, particularly men, face a crisis of identity and purpose post-retirement. This can lead to serious health implications - even earlier deaths soon after their well-deserved retirement.

"If we are not needed, why live at all?"

Legions of men focus all their effort, energy, and self-worth on career success rather than quality relationships. And more and more women are starting to repeat that same mistake.

You are not your job. As we detach our self-worth from our job roles, we become more resilient to such transitions.

By perceiving our career not as a defining part of our identity but rather as a dynamic and enjoyable game, we open ourselves to new opportunities. This approach increases our psychological safety, making us more adaptable and efficient.

When we view technologies such as LLMs as tools to play with rather than threats to our jobs, we can disrupt our own roles in positive ways, leading to greater success and fulfillment.

So, where should we draw self-confidence and identity from if not from our jobs?

The answer, in my opinion, is profound:

If somebody loves you, you are still needed by them.

If you have loving relationships, your feeling of self-worth becomes antifragile against disruptive change. More robots and AI agents lead to higher productivity, which reduces the need for human work.

Let's take the PoV of the older man or woman you will be. You'll most certainly regret not spending more time with your loved ones. You won't regret spending less time at work - especially as machines disrupt your work.

The singularity is here, and it'll gift us flexibility and freedom. We should embrace it not as a threat but as an exciting opportunity for growth and focus on what truly matters in our lives - quality relationships, love, and health.

From this perspective, disruptions help us obtain more confidence and self-worth.

As individuals, I believe it's best if we reach the mindset that technological disruption is just a multiplayer game providing us with magical items and alien tech LLMs to level up our gameplay.

This not only safeguards our mental and emotional well-being but also positions us on the right side of change, ready to thrive in an ever-evolving world.

Be on the right side of change. 🚀
Chris

 

👩‍💻 Action step: Chill out at your job today - don't take it too seriously.

subject: 5 Tech Articles of the Week
body:
Hey {User},

Before we start in the week, let's recap the week in five Finxter articles.

(1) In the first article, I've done some original research on whether offering ChatGPT a tip really improves performance. I tested several amounts and measured the impact:

Finxter Research on the Tipping Prompt

(2) The second article introduces a new LLM that performs really well and already ranks on some leaderboards (GPT-4 is still better):

Starling-7B: UC Berkeley’s New Open-Source LLM

(3) Google's brand-new Nature paper presents GNoME, i.e., an AI model that is already being used in research to discover 2.2 million new crystal materials with real-world impact:

Google Deep Learning – 800 Years of Human Experimentation in One Discovery

(4) If you're experimenting with GPTs, check out this one that I found last week - it integrates with a database of tens of thousands of GPTs that were already built by developers like you and me:

This Meta GPT Helps You Find the Best GPT

(5) Finally, this article talks about the book "The Star Principle - How It Can Make You Rich" by Richard Koch, a highly successful entrepreneur and investor.

Richard has amassed multiple nine figures of net worth without working very hard, so we might learn something from him:

3 Easy Steps to Avoid Being Disrupted by AI

Have a great start in the week - talk tomorrow!

Be on the right side of change! 🚀
Chris

subject: How I Created a Code Translator Using GPT-3
body:
Hey {User},

I am not a rocket scientist - and chances are you're not one either.

Luckily, we don't need to be rocket scientists to create helpful little apps that make the world a better place.

Here's a simple app by Kwame, an avid reader of the Finxter newsletter, that has the DNA to become something bigger and more powerful when its creator decides to keep working on it and improve it continuously: 👇

[Blog] How I Created a Code Translator Using GPT-3

Check it out, it's a fun read. I learned something valuable myself about easy AWS app deployment!

Yet, the purpose of this email is not only to show you how you can start helpful little tools using LLMs easily and quickly as a complete beginner. I also want to challenge you to think of creative little ways to solve your own problems with LLM APIs.

Then seek user feedback on Reddit or Twitter/X or share your app with me. User feedback is gold: incorporate the feedback and build your little app until you believe it's as good as you can make it.

I've personally talked to dozens of Finxter readers over the years who have started with a small idea, thrown themselves into the community with a value-oriented, helpful attitude and built impressive businesses and applications.

You can do it. Building helpful apps is not rocket science, especially with powerful helpers like ChatGPT!

Let's be on the right side of change! 🚀
Chris

subject: Sorry we wasted your time
body:
Hey {User},

While walking today, I remembered my lovely days as a University student.

... Sitting on the floor due to overcrowded lecture halls, listening to theoretical computer science professors who had already lost 90% of the students after 10 minutes of talking ... 🎶

Here's a provocative question: Why is it common practice to waste students' time in many universities?

Shouldn't students be treated more like valued customers rather than unwelcome disturbances from the real work (=research)?

While I cannot speak for all people in academia, I'm definitely guilty even though I love teaching: my strategy to catch up with pressing research tasks was to avoid teaching effort as much as humanly possible.

In hindsight, two features were missing for an efficient and modern learning experience: 

  1. A pause button ⏹️, and
  2. A personal tutor I could ask "dumb questions" right when I lost the plot while everybody waits until I get it.

Fortunately, you can now get what I couldn't! That's why I've spent my afternoon today (and $500 per month on OpenAI tokens) launching FinxterGPT on the Academy:

🧑‍💻👉 https://academy.finxter.com/

If you're a premium member, you can now pause each Finxter Academy course video and ask GPT-4 Turbo for clarification or even code right where and when you need it. 🤩

And if you're not a premium member, you can still use Finxter GPT-4 Turbo on any blog post, but with lower priority and slightly more token restrictions.

Be on the right side of change! 🚀
Chris

body:

59.8 percent of the US workforce are white-collar workers.

Most of us will eventually be disrupted by AI tools. And many can already be replaced by large language models... 👇

[Blog] 11 Profitable Ways to Make Money as a Prompt Engineer (2023)

... as a result, much of the work FORCE 💪 in our society will be unleashed, much like when we transitioned from 99% to 1% of worker time spent on producing food.

Fortunately! Because this transition causes significant prosperity for society overall. However, some will be on the wrong side of change.

As a prompt engineer, you have a unique set of skills that can lead to many opportunities for generating income by being on the right side of change, i.e., you help businesses leverage AI to increase profitability and efficiency and create value for society, yourself, and your loved ones.

Read the blog for 11 simple (but not easy) ideas to make money as a prompt engineer!

subject: 5 Weekly Tech Resources
body:
Hey {User},

Let's recap last week's most interesting Finxter articles:

The first article gives you access to a blazingly fast new LLM, better than LLaMA 2 and faster than ChatGPT. You can use it for free:

🔗 (1) Blog: Mixtral 8x7B Outperforms LLaMA 2 and Beats ChatGPT in Speed by 21x to 44x!

The second article shows you a strategy for hiring freelancers if you want to scale up your growing online company:

🔗 (2) Blog: Merit-Based Iterative Testing (MBIT) – A Business Strategy to Building a Meritocracy with Freelancers

The third article gives you a glimpse into the future - ubiquitous and ambient intelligence:

🔗 (3) Blog: LLM in a Flash – Apple’s Attempt to Inject Intelligence Into the Edge

The fourth article provides unique novel research on the role-playing prompting technique - a must-read for prompt engineers! 👇

🔗 (4) Blog: Exploring Role-Play Prompting LLMs – What Does Science Say?

Finally, the fifth article gives you a full guide on scraping Upwork to get a small but sustainable edge on the largest freelancing marketplace in the world:

🔗 (5) Blog: Improve Your Upwork Job Search with RSS and Data Scraping

Lastly, check out our new WhatsApp group we launched this week. We're already 100 subscribers strong! 💯

(Only 99,900 subscribers to go.) 😅

Have a beautiful weekend with your loved ones. Let's talk tomorrow!

Be on the right side of change! 🚀
